entry.title: Streamline Supplier Onboarding in Ariba SLP: Reduce Friction, Cut Cycle Time, and Measure Success
entry.content:
Supplier onboarding on Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP) within the SAP Business Network is often the first meaningful interaction suppliers have with your procurement ecosystem. A smooth onboarding experience reduces manual work, speeds time-to-value, and improves supplier relationships.

In this post I want to cover common supplier challenges, buyer-side actions helping to shorten cycle time, and some of the KPIs to be tracked by procurement teams providing better visibility into the process. 

Common supplier pain points

Buyer organizations often observe their suppliers struggling with their SAP Business Network registrations, when accessing it for the first time. 

  • Registration confusion: suppliers are uncertain whether their organization already exists on the SAP Business Network (BN) or which link to use to register.
  • Missing administrators: suppliers don‚Äôt know who their BN company account administrator is and try to register new accounts.
  • Duplicate accounts: suppliers create new accounts believing their organization isn‚Äôt present, causing activations being blocked. 
  • Forgotten credentials: password resets and account recovery add delays and confusion.
  • Hard-to-navigate BN UI: suppliers struggle to find questionnaires, documents, or required pages.
  • Incomplete questionnaires: required fields or attachments are missed, causing rework.

 

What buying organizations can do (practical options)

What suppliers see during the onboarding is mostly controlled by the Buyers . Better design and support from buyers helps to reduce supplier drop-off and errors.

  1. Proactive discovery and outreach
    Query BN data to detect suppliers already present and send a branded email linking to their organization with a single call-to-action and a short checklist, expected timeline and contact for help.

    If an organization exists on the BN, present a ‚Äúwe found your organization ‚Äî confirm this is you‚Äù option instead of forcing a fresh registration. Provide clear steps for finding or assigning the BN administrator.

  2. Direct invites and pre-population
    Issue SLP onboarding invitations that pre-fill known fields (company name, tax ID, address), so suppliers only confirm or correct values,  and link directly to the exact questionnaire page.

  3. Map administrators and publish escalation paths
    Maintain a directory of supplier admin contacts. If unknown, require admin confirmation during outreach and provide a buyer-side escalation contact with a published SLA (e.g., respond within 24 business hours).

  4. Prevent duplicate accounts
    Add a ‚Äúhow to search for your organization‚Äù guide (screenshots) in outreach. If duplicates appear, pause onboarding workflows and assist with merging or linking accounts.

    Use VAT, DUNS, or registration-number matching during invite and submission. When a match is found, offer the supplier options to claim, request a merge, or request buyer assistance rather than blocking them.

  5. Make password recovery obvious and fast
    Include password-reset links in invites and onboarding emails, plus a short FAQ and a time-limited chat/phone support window for account issues.

  6. Simplify questionnaires & UI guidance
    Keep questionnaires minimal and use conditional fields to hide irrelevant questions. Provide field-level hints, acceptable file types, and a 2‚Äì3 minute walkthrough video showing where to find forms and how to upload documents.

  7. Use validations and automated checks
    Enable SLP format validations (VAT/tax ID, bank account patterns) and implement automated acceptance rules to fast-track suppliers meeting baseline criteria.

  8. Offer dedicated support & fast-track channels
    Run onboarding clinics (live and recorded) and provide ‚Äúconcierge‚Äù onboarding for strategic suppliers.
    Route complex or high-risk cases to a verification team with committed response times (e.g., 24‚Äì48 hours), and notify suppliers about expected timelines.

  9. Internal governance & training
    Define owner roles, SLAs for response/activation, and train procurement, master-data, and supplier enablement teams on SLP workflows and common supplier issues.

Practical messaging examples

Customizing invitation emails, or sending your own personalized invitations before slicking "INVITE" button in the application can set up the tone of the registration procedure and contribute to smoother interactions of suppliers with the "new system". Sample invitation message may contain the following elements:

Invite subject: ‚ÄúAction required: Complete your registration to transact with [BuyerName] on SAP Business Network‚Äù

Email body: link to organization page, estimated time (10‚Äì15 minutes), checklist (admin contact, VAT, banking, certificates), link to 2-minute walkthrough, and buyer support email + SLA.

Troubleshooting snippet: ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt find your company? Search by registration number. Still not found ‚Äî reply to this email and our team will assist.‚Äù

 

KPIs to track (what to measure and why)

KPIs show you what's actually working (or not). Providing help with identifying bottlenecks they can help you to focus on areas needing fixes. Without them, organizations are effectively flying blind.

  • Invite open rate ‚Äî % of invites opened. Low values point to delivery or messaging issues. Measure via email analytics weekly.
  • Time to Onboard (median & 95th percentile) ‚Äî time from invite/request to Active status; track median and 95th percentile; aim to reduce it.
  • First-pass Completion Rate ‚Äî % of registrations accepted without rework; indicates questionnaire clarity.
  • Duplicate Account Rate ‚Äî % of onboardings that create duplicates requiring merge; high rates signal discovery or invite targeting issues.
  • Supplier Admin Identified Rate ‚Äî % of suppliers that verify an administrator within SLA; critical for handoffs.
  • Support contacts per 100 suppliers ‚Äî help tickets/calls during onboarding; indicates need for clearer guidance or UI fixes.
  • Support Ticket Volume & SLA Compliance ‚Äî onboarding-related tickets and percent resolved within target SLA.
  • Questionnaire Completion Quality Score ‚Äî composite score of completeness, document validity, and correct formats.
  • Drop-off Rate by Step (funnel) ‚Äî % who start but do not complete each stage (invite ‚Üí start ‚Üí upload docs ‚Üí submit ‚Üí activate).
  • Supplier satisfaction (post-onboarding) ‚Äî short survey (1‚Äì2 questions) in the welcome email to capture qualitative feedback.

Suggested targets (this is an example, adjust for your own situation):

  • Invite open rate: >60%
  • Questionnaire completion: >70% within 7 days
  • Median time to activation: <7 days for standard suppliers; <48 hours for low-risk
  • Duplicate rate: <3%
  • Support tickets per 100 suppliers: <5

 

Quick wins (first 30 days)

  • Send a standardized invite with checklist and direct links.
  • Trim questionnaires to essentials and add conditional fields.
  • Publish a short ‚ÄúHow to register‚Äù walkthrough with screenshots.
  • Set and communicate a 24‚Äì48 hour SLA for onboarding support.
  • Start tracking Time to Onboard and First-pass Completion Rate.

 

90-day program (roadmap)

  1. Month 1: Implement quick wins and set up KPI dashboards (Time to Onboard, First-pass Completion).
  2. Month 2: Run onboarding clinics, enable pre-fill invites, and add automated validation rules.
  3. Month 3: Analyze funnel drop-offs, refine questionnaires, offer concierge onboarding for strategic suppliers, and report improvements to stakeholders.

Key takeaways

  • Prioritize removing manual steps, pre-populating known data, and providing clear, actionable guidance to suppliers.
  • Measure both speed (Time to Onboard) and quality (First-pass Completion, Duplicate Account Rate, questionnaire quality).
  • Combine proactive outreach, streamlined forms, automated validations, user guidance, and a defined support SLA to minimize rework and shorten cycle time.

entry.title: Read Confirmation in SAP Signavio ‚Äì How to Automate It with SAP Signavio Process Governance
entry.content:
Read Confirmation is a simple yet highly relevant governance requirement in many organizations:
Employees must confirm that they have read and understood a procedure, policy, or process update.

In SAP Signavio, there are two ways to handle read confirmations ‚Äì the built-in capability in SAP Signavio Process Manager, and a fully customizable approach using SAP Signavio Process Governance (SPG).
In this blog post, I will show both options and then focus on how you can build a flexible, automated, and auditable read-confirmation workflow using Process Governance.

Why Read Confirmation Matters

Organizations face a variety of regulatory, compliance, and operational demands ‚Äî whether in procurement, finance, HR, operations, or IT.
Ensuring that employees not only receive process updates but also acknowledge and understand them is essential for:

  • Compliance & audit readiness

  • Reducing operational risk

  • Increasing process transparency

  • Ensuring consistent process execution

Option 1: Standard Read Confirmation in SAP Signavio Process Manager

SAP Signavio Process Manager provides a standard feature to collect read confirmations directly on diagram level.

You can assign:

  • A single user

  • Multiple users

  • A user group

  • Multiple user groups

The confirmation status is displayed in the diagram header, and you can export the confirmation list if needed.

 

This option works well for simple use cases.
However, many customers require more advanced logic such as:

  • Automatically requesting confirmation for all ‚ÄúProcurement processes‚Äù by all ‚ÄúBuyers‚Äù

  • Running confirmations after every approval workflow

  • Storing results in a central, tabular report

  • Triggering reminders or escalations

  • Displaying confirmation status directly in the Collaboration Hub

This is where SAP Signavio Process Governance becomes extremely powerful.

Option 2: Fully Customizable Read Confirmations with SAP Signavio Process Governance

SAP Signavio Process Governance allows organizations to automate governance activities across the entire process lifecycle.
These include among many others moving models, updating dictionary items, archiving, model health checks, ownership transfers, publishing/ unpublishing workflows, BPMN exports, document creation, and much more.
(See the official capabilities described in the Feature Scope Description and User Guide .)

Among these use cases, Read Confirmation stands out as one of the simplest to configure, yet one of the most impactful.

Scenario: Read Confirmation Automatically After a Process Approval Workflow

In this example, we enhance an existing BPMN approval workflow so that after the diagram is approved a read confirmation is automatically sent to a specific user group.
The confirmation will say: ‚ÄúI have read and understood the BPMN.‚Äù
The result will be visible in the SAP Signavio Collaboration Hub, and you can export all confirmations via SPG Analytics.

Step-by-Step Configuration

Step 1: Copy or Import Your Existing Approval Workflow

Open SAP Signavio SAP Signavio Process Governance and simply copy an existing approval workflow template.

To avoid changing the original workflow, I downloaded it, renamed it, and uploaded it again as a separate version.

 

Step 2: Add a Read Confirmation Step

After the final approval event, add a User Task to the workflow.

Inside the form builder, add a Yes/No checkbox with the label:

‚ÄúI understood and read the BPMN!‚Äù

This becomes the mandatory confirmation.

 

Step 3: Define the Recipients (General Tab)

Under General, select who must confirm the reading ‚Äî
for example:

  • A specific user

  • A whole user group

  • One or multiple departments

This allows automated role-based governance.

Step 4: Configure Reminders (Optional)

If employees forget to confirm, automated reminders can be configured directly in the task settings.

Reminders help enforce compliance without manual follow-up.

 

Step 5: Publish Your Workflow

Once published, this workflow is available and ready to execute.
Every time a process goes through approval, the read confirmation is triggered automatically.

 

Step 6: Use SPG Analytics for Reporting

Create a dedicated reporting area in Analytics to download CSV reports.
This gives you a tabular list of:

  • Who confirmed

  • When they confirmed

  • Which process

  • Status (open / completed)

     

     

Optional: This data can be exported or integrated via the Analytics API.

Step 7: Test the Workflow

Run a quick test to make sure:

  • The approval triggers the confirmation

  • The checkbox appears correctly

  • The confirmation is logged

  • The status displays in Collaboration Hub

  • Report data is captured as expected

  • We created a video for you to show the hole process 

Summary:

Read Confirmation is not just a checkbox it is a vital part of governance, compliance, and operational excellence.

While SAP Signavio  offers a simple built-in feature, SAP Signavio Process Governance allows you to design end-to-end, automated, and fully customized read-confirmation workflows that fit your organization's governance model.

The setup is straightforward far easier than most expect and offers huge value in ensuring accountability and compliance.

And because it seems mandatory to mention Artificial Intelligence everywhere these days, here is the official disclaimer:
This workflow can be fully built and executed without any AI at all üòâ. 

At this point I want to thank @annika1998 for her consistent support! Check out her LinkedIn.

entry.title: Re: Issue with CDS Join for SD & FI Documents for Custom...
entry.content:
Unfortunately, the first view contains too many errors from FIN point of view.

- wrong join condition BKPF ACDOCA
- join not needed .. use the _JournalEntry Association in I_JournalEntryItem
- missing fields (Ledger, FiscalYear , ...)
- fields used with wrong semantic
- some more ...

I do not know your goal. So, I have for you a proposal view as starting view.
It has the ACDOCA as main view and then only [0..1] associations.


Please use this view with a strong filter (Ledger, CompanyCode, LedgerFiscalYear, ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK', ....)

-----------------------------------------
define view entity ZXX_JEI_VBRK as select from I_JournalEntryItem as JEI
//association [0..1] to I_BillingDocument as _BillingDocument on $projection.ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK' .....
association [0..1] to I_BillingDocumentBasic as _BillingDocument on $projection.ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK'
and $projection.ReferenceDocumentContext = ''
and $projection.ReferenceDocument = _BillingDocument.BillingDocument

//association [0..1] to I_BillingDocumentItem as _BillingDocumentItem on $projection.ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK' .....
association [0..1] to I_BillingDocumentItemBasic as _BillingDocumentItem on $projection.ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK'
and $projection.ReferenceDocumentContext = ''
and $projection.ReferenceDocument = _BillingDocumentItem.BillingDocument
and $projection.ReferenceDocumentItem = _BillingDocumentItem.BillingDocumentItem
{
key JEI.SourceLedger,
key JEI.CompanyCode, // needed for association to JournalEntry
key JEI.FiscalYear, // needed for association to JournalEntry
key JEI.AccountingDocument, // needed for association to JournalEntry
key JEI.LedgerGLLineItem,
key JEI.Ledger, // filter on Ledger is mandatory .. otherwise double/wrong data
JEI.LedgerFiscalYear,

JEI.FiscalYearVariant,
JEI.ControllingArea,
JEI.ChartOfAccounts,

JEI.ReferenceDocumentType,
JEI.ReferenceDocumentContext,
JEI.ReferenceDocument,
JEI.ReferenceDocumentItem,

JEI.PostingDate,
JEI.AccountingDocumentType,

JEI.SalesDocument,
JEI.SalesDocumentItem,
JEI.Plant,

// more fields from ACDOCA
// JEI.<field>

// more fields from BKPF if really needed
JEI._JournalEntry.DocumentReferenceID,
// JEI._JournalEntry.<field>

// more fields from VBRK
_BillingDocument.BillingDocument,
_BillingDocument.BillingDocumentType,
// _BillingDocument.<field>

// more fields from VBRP
_BillingDocumentItem.BillingDocumentItem // here we can have the NULL value
// _BillingDocumentItem.<field>

}
where JEI.ReferenceDocumentType = 'VBRK'
and JEI.Ledger = '0L'
and JEI.CompanyCode = '0001'
and JEI.LedgerFiscalYear = '2025'
-----------------------------------------

entry.title: Design Fiori Apps in Figma
entry.content:
Why SAP Fiori is the Future

With SAP Fiori, users not only get more modern applications but can also use apps via mobile devices like tablets or smartphones.

The SAP world is gradually shifting towards Fiori. Old technologies like SAP GUI or WDA are becoming things of the past, being replaced by the modern look and feel of Fiori interfaces.

Users benefit from a significantly better user experience. The individual apps are more consistent and uniform, which supports new users or occasional users in working smoothly. A fact that shouldn‚Äôt be underestimated is that 80% of all users in the Fiori environment use apps only occasionally (approx. 2 hours/week) and therefore don't know every app inside out.

But power users also benefit from Fiori apps and the new features they bring. SAP Fiori paves the way for AI - for instance, SAP‚Äôs new AI assistant ‚ÄúJoule‚Äù can be used directly within Fiori apps.

So, SAP Fiori opens up numerous potentials - for a modern look and feel, but also for utilizing the numerous standard applications that SAP provides in the Fiori Apps Library.

Designing Your Own Fiori Apps is the Right Way to Go!

Creating screen designs for SAP Fiori apps makes it possible to gather feedback from users at an early stage.

However, if the SAP standard doesn't fit your specific requirements, the best path is to design and develop your own Fiori apps. This way, you can create the best possible solution for your users and maintain full control over the associated processes and workflows.

Ideally, you can involve Key Users directly in the design of new Fiori apps. In the end, this ensures high user acceptance and happy users.

Designing Fiori Apps with Figma

Figma is a very well-known prototyping tool that UX designers typically use to create screendesigns and click dummies for new apps and websites. While the tool isn't specifically geared only towards SAP Fiori, it works excellently for designing Fiori apps when combined with the templates provided by SAP (the SAP Fiori Design Stencils).

It pays off to design Fiori apps with a tool like Figma before they go into development. This makes the planned solution tangible before investing the huge effort that comes with technical development. Future users can give their feedback based on screendesigns, allowing the Fiori app to be optimized directly. This guarantees an optimal solution without having to make many expensive adjustments to the productive app later on.

Designing Fiori apps in Figma specifically means that we create screendesigns. Such screendesigns show in true-to-life detail how the Fiori app will actually look in the end. The differences compared to the final development are minimal.

We can also easily arrange the Fiori screendesigns in Figma into click prototypes. This allows interactions and user flows (e.g., opening dialogs or navigating between screens) to be demonstrated clearly.

Note: Fiori apps can be designed in great detail in Figma. The final screendesigns are often indistinguishable from the implementation. Interactions like navigation between screens or dialogs can also be implemented easily in Figma.

Tutorial: How You Can Design Fiori Apps with Figma

1. Install Figma

Download page of the Figma desktop client.

Figma is the best tool for designing Fiori apps - precisely because SAP officially supports it by providing design templates. Figma can be used both in the browser and as an installed version.

Personally, I would recommend installing Figma, as the performance is often slightly better than in the browser. You can find the download on the official website:

In any case, you will need a free Figma account, which you should create now.

2. Install SAP Fiori Fonts

SAP page for downloading the required fonts "72" and "Business Icon Font".

To work seamlessly with the Fiori templates in Figma, you need to quickly install two fonts on your PC.

First is the SAP font "72", which you can download from SAP here:

And second is the "Business Icon" font, which you can download from SAP here:

Unzip both .zip files and then install the fonts.

3. Open Fiori Templates in Figma (SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit)

Figma page of the SAP S/4HANA WEB UI Kit ‚Äì the official Fiori design templates from SAP for use in Figma.

To start creating designs for Fiori apps in Figma, it is necessary to open the official templates from SAP. These templates contain all the UI elements that exist in Fiori. From buttons, tables, or selection fields to complete pages and Fiori floorplans, such as the List Report or the Object Page, you will find everything you need here to design Fiori apps.

SAP provides different templates depending on whether you are creating a Fiori app for the Web, Android, or iOS. However, in 90% of cases, you will be designing your own Fiori apps for your SAP S/4HANA. Therefore, you can find the suitable templates here:

Note: SAP updates and expands this template regularly. Therefore, it is worth re-importing the Fiori templates every few months!

4. Overview of Fiori Templates in Figma

View of Figma with the opened page "List Report" from the "SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit".

Once you have opened the Web UI Kit in Figma, you should see a long list of "Pages" in the left area of Figma. In these many pages, you will find the individual UI elements and templates of SAP Fiori that you can now use.

Take a few moments to get an overview. For example, on the "Buttons" page, we find all the numerous button types of Fiori. Under "Responsive Table," you will find something more complex: the tables you can use in your Fiori apps. And if you scroll down very far, you will find layout templates for all Fiori Elements floorplans under "List Report," for example.

And exactly this template is what we will grab in the next step!

Design Your First Fiori App with Fiori Elements Templates

From my experience as a Fiori UX Designer, 90% of all Fiori apps are implemented using Fiori Elements. Fiori Elements is a way to accelerate the development (and design) of custom Fiori apps by using ready-made templates ("floorplans"). If you've ever seen a Fiori app, you've most likely seen such a floorplan.

For our first Fiori app, we will also use such a floorplan as a foundation to speed up the design process while building a solid solution.

The Idea for Our Fictional Fiori App

Sketch of our planned Fiori app.

Our Fiori app should fulfill the following fictional use case:

  • On an overview: List all invoices my company has sent to customers and make them filterable.

  • On a detail view: Provide comprehensive information regarding a specific invoice.

From this use case, it follows that we need two screendesigns: the overview and the detail view. Ideally, we can use two classic Fiori Elements floorplans here: the List Report (for the overview) and the Object Page (for the detail view).

Designing a List Report in Figma

Copying the "List Report" into a new Figma file as a starting point for our Fiori app.

So let's start with the List Report. To do this, we open the previously opened Fiori templates in Figma again and go to the "List Report" page. There, we copy the layer "XL 1440px" on the left side and paste it into a new Figma file.

We can create a new Figma file by clicking on the small Figma icon in the top left -> File -> New Design File. In the new design file, you then paste the List Report template with Ctrl + V!

What you see now is an existing template for a List Report - the perfect starting point for our design. This template contains sample data that doesn't fit our fictional Fiori app - but we can change that quite easily.

Adjusting Texts

Adjusting texts in the "List Report". Here we are changing the column headers as an example ‚Äì in principle, all texts can be adjusted as desired!

If you press "T" and then click on an existing text with the mouse cursor, you can change it. With this, you can now adjust, for example, filter names, column headers, or texts in the tables and buttons.

Note: If changing a text is not possible, it might be that the required fonts are not installed. If changes are not possible despite installed fonts, I recommend using the Figma desktop client.

Deleting UI Elements

Deleting unneeded elements is done by selecting and pressing the "Delete" key. In this example, I am deleting some unneeded filters from the header.

If you no longer need elements, you can delete them. To do this, you have to click on the corresponding element and then press "Delete".

 

Note: You might have to click on an element multiple times to select it, as you are essentially clicking through the hierarchy in the design. This way, you can now delete filters, buttons, or table rows. If you make a mistake, you can undo it with Ctrl + Z.

Adapting UI Elements

Almost every Fiori UI element can be customized. To do this, you can select an element and see the associated settings options in the panel on the right side. In the example, I am changing the button style of the "Create" button.

Many UI elements can also be customized. For example, if you select the "Create" button, you will see properties on the right side that you can change. If you change the Type to "Primary", for instance, the button becomes a primary button and gets a blue background. You can adjust the look and feel of very many UI elements according to your wishes. Feel free to try out all options - you can't do anything wrong! üòâ

You can now also select the table ("Responsive Table") in the design and choose the value "Columns" for the "Structure" property. This ensures that you can adjust (delete or add) the individual columns of the table more easily.

For Our Example Fiori App

In our example, I am now adjusting the texts in the filters and the table according to the use case. I am removing unneeded filters and columns in the table. The end result is our List Report of the invoices!

Our final screen design for the overview page of our fictional Fiori app. Based on the floorplan, filters, columns, and buttons, for example, were adapted.

Designing an Object Page in Figma

Adapting the "Object Page" floorplan in Figma. Here I am removing some unneeded elements and adjusting the text of the title.

Now we want to create the detail page for a single invoice for our fictional Fiori app. To do this, we go back to the Fiori templates and switch to the "Object Page". Here we now see different variations of the Object Page for different screen sizes.

We simply click on the Object Page variant that is at the very top left, copy it again to the clipboard, and paste it into our Figma design where we have also placed the List Report.

Similar to the List Report, we can adapt the individual UI elements of the Object Page as we please - meaning we can: change texts, adapt or remove elements.

Adapting the Floorplan for Our Example Fiori App

Our detail page of an invoice, fully designed in Figma.

In our example, we primarily remove some UI elements that we don't need - for example, the graphic and the popover at the top left. We adjust texts and tables so that it fits our use case.

Prototyping: Linking the List Report and Object Page

After switching to "Prototype" mode, navigation from the overview page to the detail page can be implemented via drag-and-drop.

We have now designed two very simple views for our Fiori app. Now we can go a step further and insert interactions.

For this example, we will add navigation from the List Report page to the Object Page, as this is an integral part of our planned app.

To do this, we first have to switch to "Prototype" mode - we do this by clicking on the "Prototype" tab in the top right panel.

Then we select the arrow in the last column of the table from the List Report and drag-and-drop an arrow onto the Object Page.

Subsequently, we can also test the interaction in presentation mode. To do this, we select the List Report and click on the Play button at the top right. This opens a new tab.

If we have done everything correctly, we can now navigate to the Obect Page by clicking on the arrow in the List Report table!

Opening presentation mode by selecting the "Overview Page" and clicking the "Play" button at the top right.

Congratulations - You Have Designed Your First Fiori App!

In our example, we have now created two simple screendesigns based on existing templates ("floorplans") and linked them via prototyping.

If you have made it this far: Congratulations - you have successfully designed your first Fiori app! üôÇ

Deeper Adjustments of Floorplans and Designing Complex Fiori Apps

It is often necessary and useful to expand the designs even further. In principle, every aspect of such a screendesign can be adapted and expanded in Figma. New UI elements can be added, the layouting adjusted, or interactions such as opening dialogs and navigation up to concrete features can be realized in Figma.

The implementation possibilities have no limits here. If none of the Fiori Elements floorplans fit your use case, you can also design a Fiori Freestyle App in Figma.

However, all of this requires advanced skills and techniques in handling Figma for Fiori, which I deliberately do not want to include in this beginner's guide, as they often do not achieve the desired goal without direct guidance from an expert.

Conclusion & Key Takeaways

Designing Fiori apps doesn't have to be complicated. As we have seen, using Figma combined with the official SAP templates bridges the gap between complex technical requirements and a user-friendly interface.

Here are the key takeaways from this guide:

  • User Experience First: Moving to Fiori ensures a consistent, modern, and intuitive experience for your users.

  • Visualize Before You Build: Prototyping in Figma makes the solution tangible. It allows you to gather feedback from key users early, preventing expensive changes during the actual development phase.

  • Leverage Standards: You don't need to reinvent the wheel. Using Fiori Elements floorplans (like the List Report and Object Page) speeds up the design process significantly.

  • Official Resources: The SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit in Figma provides you with everything you need to create professional and accurate designs.

Let's connect!

Do you need help or support using Figma for creating Fiori screendesigns? Or do you have specific questions about the workflow?

Feel free to send me a message or simply write a comment below this post. I am curious to hear about your experiences with designing Fiori apps!

A special thank you: Finally, I want to send a big thank you to the SAP Design Team for providing and regularly maintaining these Fiori templates for Figma. They are a massive help for the entire ecosystem and make our work as designers much easier.

Happy Designing!

entry.title: Deploying SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) on AWS Free Tier Using Terraform + Ansible + SLES
entry.content:
I‚Äôve spent a bit of time experimenting with Cloud Connectors recently and wanted a faster, cleaner way to spin one up without all the usual hassle. In this post, I build on the earlier SCC and Ansible write-ups and bring everything together into a single workflow. We‚Äôll automate the entire deployment using Terraform for provisioning and Ansible for configuration, resulting in a fully working SCC with minimal manual effort.

This guide provides a fully working, fully automated setup using:

  • Terraform for provisioning the EC2 instance
  • Ansible for OS prep and SCC installation
  • Heap tuning via props.ini for stable SCC operation

1. Directory layout

sap-lab/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run.sh
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ run_destroy.sh
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform.tfvars
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ <KEYPAIR_NAME>.pub
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ site.yml
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ inventory.ini
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ansible.cfg
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ roles/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sap_prep/
        ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tasks/main.yml
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ sap_scc/
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ defaults/main.yml
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tasks/main.yml
            ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/scc_daemon.service.j2

2. Terraform: main.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"
  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = var.region
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_scc_sg" {
  name        = "sap-scc-sg"
  description = "Allow SCC UI and SSH"
  vpc_id      = var.vpc_id

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  ingress {
    from_port   = 8443
    to_port     = 8443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_scc" {
  ami           = var.sles_ami
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
  key_name      = var.keypair_name

  subnet_id                   = var.subnet_id
  associate_public_ip_address = true
  vpc_security_group_ids      = [aws_security_group.sap_scc_sg.id]

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-LAB-SCC"
  }
}

output "ansible_inventory" {
  value = "sap_host ansible_host=${aws_instance.sap_scc.public_ip} ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=../terraform/${var.private_key} ansible_ssh_common_args='-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null'"
}

3. Terraform Variables (variables.tf)

variable "region" {}
variable "vpc_id" {}
variable "subnet_id" {}
variable "keypair_name" {}
variable "private_key" {}
variable "sles_ami" {}

4. terraform.tfvars

region       = "us-east-2"
vpc_id       = "vpc-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
subnet_id    = "subnet-xxxxxxxxxxxx"
keypair_name = "my-keypair"
private_key  = "my-keypair.pem"
sles_ami     = "ami-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"

5. Ansible config (ansible.cfg)

[defaults]
host_key_checking = False
retry_files_enabled = False

6. Role: OS Preparation (sap_prep/tasks/main.yml)

---
- name: Install prerequisites
  zypper:
    name:
      - wget
      - net-tools
      - chrony
      - unzip
      - curl
    state: present

- name: Ensure chronyd is running
  service:
    name: chronyd
    state: started
    enabled: yes

- name: Set vm.swappiness
  ansible.posix.sysctl:
    name: vm.swappiness
    value: "10"
    state: present
    reload: yes

7. SCC Role Defaults (sap_scc/defaults/main.yml)

---
scc_version: "2.16.2"
scc_file: "sapcc-{{ scc_version }}-linux-x64.zip"

scc_install_dir: /opt/sap/scc
scc_user: sccadm
scc_group: sccadm

scc_jvm_xms: "256m"
scc_jvm_xmx: "512m"

scc_service_name: scc_daemon

8. SCC Installation Tasks (sap_scc/tasks/main.yml)

---
- name: Ensure sccadm group exists
  group:
    name: "{{ scc_group }}"
    system: yes

- name: Ensure sccadm user exists
  user:
    name: "{{ scc_user }}"
    group: "{{ scc_group }}"
    shell: /sbin/nologin
    system: yes

- name: Install prerequisites
  become: yes
  zypper:
    name:
      - unzip
      - curl
      - java-17-openjdk-headless
    state: present

- name: Create installer directory
  file:
    path: /tmp/scc-installer
    state: directory

- name: Upload SCC ZIP (2.16.2)
  copy:
    src: sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip
    dest: /tmp/scc-installer/sapcc.zip

- name: Extract SCC ZIP
  unarchive:
    src: /tmp/scc-installer/sapcc.zip
    dest: /tmp/scc-installer
    remote_src: yes

- name: Locate SCC RPM
  find:
    paths: /tmp/scc-installer
    patterns: "com.sap.scc-ui-*.rpm"
  register: rpm_file

- name: Fail if SCC RPM not found
  fail:
    msg: "SCC RPM not found."
  when: rpm_file.matched == 0

- name: Install SCC RPM
  become: yes
  zypper:
    name: "{{ rpm_file.files[0].path }}"
    disable_gpg_check: yes
    state: present

# Heap tuning
- name: Tune Xms
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: '-Xms[0-9]+m'
    replace: "-Xms{{ scc_jvm_xms }}"

- name: Tune Xmx
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: '-Xmx[0-9]+m'
    replace: "-Xmx{{ scc_jvm_xmx }}"

- name: Tune NewSize
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: 'NewSize=[0-9]+m'
    replace: 'NewSize=256m'

- name: Tune MaxNewSize
  become: yes
  replace:
    path: /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
    regexp: 'MaxNewSize=[0-9]+m'
    replace: 'MaxNewSize=256m'

- name: Enable SCC daemon
  become: yes
  systemd:
    name: "{{ scc_service_name }}"
    enabled: yes

- name: Start SCC daemon
  become: yes
  systemd:
    name: "{{ scc_service_name }}"
    state: restarted

9. Systemd Template (scc_daemon.service.j2)

[Unit]
Description=SAP Cloud Connector
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=forking
User={{ scc_user }}
Group={{ scc_group }}
ExecStart=/opt/sap/scc/go.sh -start
ExecStop=/opt/sap/scc/go.sh -stop
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

10. site.yml

---
- hosts: sap_hosts
  become: true
  roles:
    - sap_prep
    - sap_scc

11. run.sh

#!/bin/bash
set -e

cd terraform
terraform init
terraform apply -auto-approve

INVENTORY=$(terraform output -raw ansible_inventory)

cd ../ansible
echo "[sap_hosts]" > inventory.ini
echo "$INVENTORY" >> inventory.ini

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml

Output (from ansible):

Outputs:

public_ip = "<PUBLIC_IP>"

PLAY [sap_hosts] *************************************************************************************************************

TASK [Gathering Facts] *******************************************************************************************************
[WARNING]: Host 'ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>' is using the discovered Python interpreter at '/usr/bin/python3.13', but future installation of another Python interpreter could cause a different interpreter to be discovered. See https://docs.ansible.com/ansible-core/2.19/reference_appendices/interpreter_discovery.html for more information.
[WARNING]: sftp transfer mechanism failed on [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]. Use ANSIBLE_DEBUG=1 to see detailed information
[WARNING]: scp transfer mechanism failed on [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]. Use ANSIBLE_DEBUG=1 to see detailed information
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Install base packages] **************************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Start chronyd] **********************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Refresh SUSE repos] *****************************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Install Java 17 (OpenJDK)] **********************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_prep : Verify Java installation] ***********************************************************************************
changed: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Ensure sccadm group exists] **********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Ensure sccadm user exists] ***********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Install prerequisites] ***************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Create installer directory] **********************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Upload SCC ZIP (2.16.2)] *************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Extract SCC ZIP] *********************************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Find SCC RPM inside extracted ZIP] ***************************************************************************
ok: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Fail if SCC RPM not found] ***********************************************************************************
skipping: [ec2-user@<PUBLIC_IP>]

TASK [sap_scc : Install SCC RPM with zypper] *********************************************************************************
changed: [ec

12. Once the SAP Cloud Connector service has started on your SUSE instance, open the administration UI in your browser.

https://<YOUR_PUBLIC_IP>:8443


 From here you can change the default password and connect the SCC up to BTP / on-prem etc.

13. run_destroy.sh

#!/bin/bash
set -e

cd terraform
terraform destroy -auto-approve
cd ..

echo "# destroyed" > ansible/inventory.ini

Conclusion

Fully automated provisioning and configuration of SAP Cloud Connector on SLES using Terraform and Ansible, with JVM tuning for AWS Free Tier.

entry.title: Expose SAP CPI Integration Flows as APIs Using SAP API Management: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite empowers businesses to integrate applications and processes efficiently. One powerful capability is exposing CPI integration flows as APIs via API Management (APIM). This enables centralized governance, security, and monitoring of APIs. In this blog, we‚Äôll cover the step-by-step process to achieve this.

Step 1: Set Up SAP Process Integration Runtime

Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Instances & Subscriptions.

  • Create Service Instance
    • Service: SAP Process Integration Runtime
    • Plan: api
    • Instance Name: e.g. CPI_API_Instance
    • Assign all roles (except security roles)Create Service Key

      Click the ‚ãÆ (three-dot menu) ‚Üí Create Service Key ‚Üí Save credentials (Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL).

Step 2: Design & Deploy a Sample iFlow

In Integration Suite:

  • Create Package:
    Navigate to Design ‚Üí Integrations & APIs ‚Üí Create Package (e.g. Demo_API_Package).

  • Build iFlow:
    Add an HTTP Sender and a Content Modifier (set sample body content).
    Deploy the iFlow.

 

 

 

Step 3: Configure API Provider with OAuth2

In API Management:

  • Create API Provider:
    Navigate to Configure ‚Üí API Providers ‚Üí Create New.
    • Name: CPI_Provider
    • Connection Type: Cloud Integration
    • Host: Use host from Service Key
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials
      • Enter Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL

 

Step 4: Create & Deploy API Proxy

  • Create API Proxy:
    Select the API Provider ‚Üí Click Discover ‚Üí Choose deployed iFlow.
    Enable OAuth and provide credentials.
    • Proxy Name: flow-api-proxy
    • Save & Deploy.

 

Step 5: Test Your API

Use Postman:

  • Paste the Proxy URL
  • Send a request
  • Confirm the response from your iFlow.

 

Conclusion

By exposing SAP CPI integration flows as managed APIs through SAP API Management, you create a robust integration layer that blends flexibility with strong governance. This approach offers several key benefits:

  • Centralized Control: Manage all APIs from a single platform, making lifecycle management simple and efficient.
  • Enhanced Security: Protect your integrations with OAuth2 and other security policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Scalability & Reusability: Reuse APIs across multiple applications and business processes, cutting down development time and effort.
  • Comprehensive Monitoring: Gain full visibility into API performance and usage with built-in analytics and dashboards.

This setup not only streamlines integration but also supports modern API-driven architectures, enabling faster innovation and better interoperability across your enterprise. As a next step, consider adding features like rate limiting, caching, and custom policies in API Management to further boost performance and security.

entry.title: The Art of Possible: Why Now Is the Time for SAP Sales and Service AI Agents in Customer Experience
entry.content:
Estimated reading time ‚âà 9‚Äì10 minutes

1. Why AI Agents in CX Now?

The timing for AI agents in customer experience couldn‚Äôt be better. We‚Äôve reached the point where rising customer expectations, the need for rapid decisions, the demand for scalable personalization, and the evolution of AI have all converged.

Together, they‚Äôre transforming how sales and service teams deliver value‚Äîand how customers experience every interaction.

Rising Customer Expectations Are Raising the Stakes

Today‚Äôs customers expect instant, effortless experiences across every touchpoint. And when they don‚Äôt get them, they leave.

  • 59% of customers abandon a brand after two negative service experiences
  • 76% of customers expect companies to understand their needs and preferences.
  • 57% of customers prefer engaging with automated systems for simple inquiries. (Source)

Traditional customer service models can‚Äôt keep up with this level of demand. AI agents can‚Äîby responding instantly, understanding customer intent, and routing issues to the right place the first time.

The Speed of Business Demands Faster Decisions

Business moves at lightning speed, and slow responses can cost revenue and reputation.

AI agents excel in fast-moving environments. They can read and process unstructured data‚Äîlike emails, chat logs, and support tickets‚Äîand turn it into actionable insights in seconds.

While human agents need time to research and analyse, AI agents can instantly access customer history, identify patterns, and make data-driven decisions in real time.

Scalable Personalization Is No Longer Optional

Customers want more than good service‚Äîthey want service that feels personal. But delivering that at scale is beyond what traditional systems can do.

With Generative AI, personalization becomes effortless. AI agents can analyse massive datasets to create tailored recommendations, custom messages, and proactive support for every individual‚Äîacross every channel, and without adding headcount.

AI Is the New Assistant for Sales & Service Teams

We‚Äôve moved far beyond basic chatbots. Today‚Äôs AI agents act as intelligent assistants, transforming how teams work and how customers interact.

They can:

  • Streamline daily operations
  • Handle complex transactions (like billing or payment extensions)
  • Maintain accuracy and compliance
  • Work 24/7, without fatigue

For human teams, that means less manual effort and more time focused on building relationships and solving complex problems that require empathy and creativity.

The Bottom Line

AI agents are no longer a futuristic idea‚Äîthey‚Äôre a business necessity.

They bring together speed, personalization, and intelligence to deliver exceptional customer experiences at scale.

The question isn‚Äôt if your organization should embrace AI agents. It‚Äôs how quickly you can start.

 

2. What is the SAP CX AI Toolkit?

The SAP CX AI Toolkit brings together embedded generative and predictive AI to deliver intelligent automation and smarter customer experiences. This cloud-native solution integrates directly into SAP CX systems, enabling businesses to automate case categorization, inquiry routing, and unstructured data processing for faster, more accurate outcomes.

Generative AI personalizes content, summaries, and recommendations, while predictive AI anticipates customer behaviour to drive proactive engagement. With capabilities like visual search, AI-powered product tagging, and role-specific insights across Sales, Service, Commerce, and the Customer Data Platform, the toolkit connects data and intelligence to create seamless, personalized interactions at every touchpoint.

 

3. The Agent Concept ‚Äî From Tasks to Outcomes?

The CX AI Toolkit represents a fundamental shift from traditional AI that merely suggests to intelligent agents that execute, automate, and guide across complete business processes in both Sales & Service V1 and V2 environments.

Agents That Execute Real Actions

Unlike conventional AI tools that provide recommendations requiring human action, CX AI agents directly execute business processes. When a customer service ticket arrives, the Classification Agent handles smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules - it doesn't just suggest a category, it automatically assigns it and routes the case to the appropriate team. The Knowledge Agent not only documents the solution but intelligently captures customer needs and usage patterns, creating structured knowledge articles and publishing them directly to your knowledge base.

Comprehensive Process Automation

These agents work together to automate complex repetitive tasks with contextual understanding. The Q&A Agent automatically searches the knowledge base and matches solutions, while simultaneously providing immediate answers to product or upgrade questions. This creates a seamless flow where AI agents can process large volumes of data to identify patterns and trends that might be overlooked by human analysis, enabling end-to-end automation rather than isolated task assistance.

Intelligent Guidance Across V1 and V2 Environments

The toolkit adapts its guidance capabilities based on the specific SAP environment:

Sales & Service Cloud V2 supports comprehensive contextual behaviours where agents work by matching the tool to the entity in focus. When you open a Service Case, the AI Tool will read the case that is currently open and will pre-fill that case for you in the AI Tool. The system maintains awareness of your workflow, with recently viewed cases appearing as suggestions during searches.

Sales Cloud V1 offers additional capabilities like the Quote Creation Agent, though this functionality is confirmed to be supported only for Sales Cloud V1 and there is no confirmed roadmap for support in Sales Cloud V2.

Process-Wide Intelligence

What sets these agents apart is their ability to maintain all the context and customer intelligence throughout the journey, while automating the time-consuming tasks. They don't just execute individual steps - they orchestrate entire workflows. For example, when a service case is resolved, the same intelligence that helped with classification and resolution now provides immediate answers to any product or upgrade questions included in the opportunity notes, ensuring no context is lost in handoffs between teams.

Ready-to-Deploy Automation

These agents are delivered through the CX AI Toolkit and work out of the box with SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud, requiring no custom development. Organizations can configure specialized AI agents that perform complex business tasks with no coding required, achieving 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks and 50% productivity boost in service teams .

The CX AI Toolkit transforms AI from a suggestion engine into an active participant in your business processes, executing tasks, automating workflows, and providing intelligent guidance that adapts to your specific SAP environment and business context.

 

4. Key Agents for Sales and Service Cloud

Agents suitable for both of Sales and Service Cloud

Q&A Agent

The Q&A Agent processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses by searching knowledge bases and matching solutions. Key capabilities include:

  • Processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses
  • Allows administrators to define specific questions answered using custom data sources, tickets, or cases
  • Provides 50% higher sales staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Instant access to the most experienced agent's knowledge
  • Works with both Sales / Service Cloud V1 and V2

Knowledge Creation Agent

The Knowledge Creation Agent analyses new tickets or cases and automatically creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA) that are published back to the source. Key capabilities include:

  • Analyses new tickets or cases and creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA)
  • Publishes articles back to the source ticket or case
  • Increases sales staff productivity by focusing on high-value customer interactions 
  • Intelligent documentation of solutions and customer usage patterns
  • Increased focus on high-value customer interactions
  • Improved customer satisfaction through better knowledge capture
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks

Sales Cloud Agent

Quote Creation Agent  

The Quote Creation Agent is designed to streamline the quote generation process. Key capabilities include:

  • Automates quote generation by monitoring Microsoft Office 365 shared mailboxes
  • Transforms incoming email requests into ready-to-send quotes
  • Increases sales efficiency and drives revenue growth by eliminating manual, repetitive work
  • Important limitation: Currently supported only for Sales Cloud V1, with no confirmed roadmap for Sales Cloud V2 support

Service Cloud Agent

Case Classification Agent

The Case Classification Agent analyses new customer service tickets and automatically classifies them based on company business requirements. This agent provides:

  • Smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules
  • Elimination of manual classification work that typically consumes valuable agent time
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Greater operational performance across service processes

5. The ‚ÄúArt of Possible‚Äù: From Classification to Knowledge Creation

It‚Äôs 3 PM on a Friday afternoon at MedTech Solutions, and Dr. Martinez, a senior support specialist, receives a new support ticket:

‚ÄúOur new imaging software keeps freezing during patient scans, causing delays in our radiology department. We‚Äôve tried restarting, but the issue persists during high-resolution scans.‚Äù

For most teams, this would mark the start of a long weekend challenge‚Äîmanual triage, frantic back-and-forths, and lost time. This is where our AI Agents step into action.

The Classification Agent in Action

Within seconds, the Classification Agent gets to work. It scans the ticket, picking up on terms like ‚Äúimaging software,‚Äù ‚Äúfreezing,‚Äù ‚Äúpatient scans,‚Äù and ‚Äúradiology.‚Äù

Instead of waiting for a human to assign it, the AI instantly tags it as a Critical Software Issue and routes it directly to the Medical Software Support team with Priority 1 status.

No delays. No confusion. Just precision routing‚Äîpowered by AI that understands the business context and works 24/7 like a digital triage expert.

The Intelligent Handoff

The ticket appears in Dr. Martinez‚Äôs queue, already enriched with context and suggested similar cases. The system‚Äôs recommendations immediately point her toward a known pattern‚Äîhigh-resolution scans causing memory strain.

With insights at her fingertips, she diagnoses the problem as a memory allocation issue and resolves it by fine-tuning the software‚Äôs buffer settings. The radiology department is back online in minutes, not hours.

The Knowledge Creation Agent Steps In

As Dr. Martinez documents her fix, the Knowledge Creation Agent automatically analyses the resolution details. Recognizing a recurring pattern, it generates a new Knowledge Base Article (KBA) titled:

‚ÄúResolving Memory Allocation Issues in High-Resolution Medical Imaging Software.‚Äù

The article is structured, formatted, and published‚Äîready for future reference by both customers and support teams.

What once required hours of manual work‚Äîclassification, resolution, documentation‚Äîhas now become a continuous learning loop powered by intelligent automation.

The Art of Possible

In this single interaction, the CX AI Toolkit transformed a complex support challenge into a self-improving process:

  • The Classification Agent ensured the ticket reached the right expert immediately.
  • The Knowledge Creation Agent turned the solution into reusable knowledge.
  • And Dr. Martinez? She focused on solving problems, not managing workflows.

This is the Art of the Possible‚Äîwhere AI doesn‚Äôt just assist but learns, acts, and teaches, creating a smarter, faster, and more connected customer experience.

 

6. Architecture

In the following diagram discover our architecture in which all of enterprise data is flowing from different data sources (SAP, Microsoft or Custom ones) into a secure foundation (more details in the section 7. Governance & Trust). AI Services transform this data into intelligence through search, reasoning and orchestration. This intelligence powers the CX AI Toolkit, where tools for content creation, Q&A, intelligent search, and even custom AI agents come together.

Finally, these capabilities appear wherever teams work‚Äîinside the web application, a Chrome extension, or fully embedded experiences‚Äîbringing AI directly into every sales and service moment.

 

7. Governance & Trust

 The SAP CX AI Toolkit operates through a six-step Trusted AI Layer that ensures secure and ethical AI processing:

  1. Secure Data Retrieval: Adheres to SAP's best practices, ensuring only relevant data is accessible through user credentials when pulling information from connected systems
  2. SAP Context Grounding: Utilizes Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) concepts to enrich GenAI prompts with comprehensive ancillary information surrounding data objects to enhance output quality
  3. Obfuscation and Bias Prevention: Implements robust obfuscation techniques, hashing all identifiable information and replacing it with temporary placeholders across all fields. This process also aids in bias prevention by filtering out sensitive attributes like gender or nationality
  4. Zero Data Retention: Ensures all data transmitted to LLM services is securely deleted after each transaction, significantly reducing the risk of proprietary data exposure
  5. Audit Logs: Maintains rigorous audit logs aligned with SAP guidelines, providing Trace IDs for error tracking
  6. Human in the Loop: Emphasizes preventing automatic data dissemination without validation, acknowledging that GenAI outputs require human oversight

SAP ensures transparency through:

  • Documentation and UI Indicators: Clear marking of AI systems and effective communication of their capabilities and limitations
  • Post-hoc Explanation Tools: Implementation of tools like SHAP and LIME for explainable AI
  • Traceable Systems: All AI systems must be traceable and transparent in their operations

Users maintain full transparency and control over their data through:

  • Centralized Dashboard: Full transparency and control over data through a central dashboard
  • Anonymized Data Processing: Customer data combines accuracy with uncompromised security through anonymization
  • No Third-Party Training: SAP does not share customer data with external vendors for model training

Governance Structure

SAP's responsible AI implementation includes:

  • Global AI Ethics Steering Committee: Senior SAP leaders reviewing approach, processes, and product capabilities
  • AI Ethics Advisory Panel: Additional governance body ensuring ethical compliance
  • Regular Review Processes: Continuous evaluation and updates of ethical guidelines

SAP's approach to responsible AI is built on a comprehensive framework that ensures ethical, secure, and compliant AI development and deployment across all business applications. The company has established itself as a leader in responsible AI practices through rigorous governance structures and adherence to international standards.

 

8. How to Get Started

To start with AI Toolkit, it‚Äôs necessary to set clearly defined and measurable objectives for AI agent implementation, while prioritizing Data Quality.

Find about how you can start with the implementation and get use of Multi-Model Support Architecture here: Setting Up your SAP CX AI Toolkit System | SAP Help Portal

Helpful assets: 

  • Discovery Center - AI Capabilities
  • Discovery Center - AI Estimator
  • SAP CX AI Toolkit | SAP Help Portal
  • See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service

In the SAP Road Map Explorer you can find out what is planned for future releases of the AI Toolkit, but also what we have already upgraded in the past. 

If you would like to check what is coming to Agentic technology in Sales Cloud V2, we suggest you, visit Unleashing Agentic AI in SAP Sales Cloud V2 : Her... - SAP Community

 

9. Partnership between Humans and AI Agents

The art of the possible with AI agents in sales and service isn't just about what technology can do‚Äîit's about what humans and AI can achieve together as partners. AI Agents are ideal partners for use cases that are mentioned in the article because the time used to train and prepare is insignificant compared to time and cost savings they deliver over time.

What is important to always have on your mind? AI Agents will always need human guidance to understand urgency from customer or to sense need for different kind of assistance, no matter how much we train them. This is why humans need to master AI Mastermind and unlock the full potential of this partnership!

entry.title: "No authorized user found" for Open Connector
entry.content:
Hello together.

I¬¥m doing the tutorial "Establish Connection Between Your BambooHR Trial and Open Connectors" ( https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/btp-integration-suite-nonsapconnectivity-openconnectors.html).

When I click "Discover Connectors" I got forwarded to a logon page. There I log on with my only user (which happens to be my sap universal id) and then get the following error message.

<message>No authorized user found. Please contact your administrator to obtain access. More details see SAP Note : https://me.sap.com/notes/3035458</message>

The SAP-Note that comes with the error message does not help. Since it is for users that did not activate the capabilty. But since I do only have one user, the user who activated the capabilty is the same as the one tries to open it.

Does anybody has any idea what I¬¥m doing wrong?

 

Also the other blog entry about this topic "https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/open-connector-no-authorized-user-found/qaq-p/12793663" seems not to fit my problem. There is also quoted: "The person who has subscribed to the Integration Suite initially would have the admin access to the Open Connectors". But this is my user too, so again I should have acces with admin right, regarding this post.

 

Kind regards

 Patrick

Also it will only accept digits, no alphanumerical characters, special character etc...

Instead, I thought about using the Prefix field in the CBC activity 103636 which really seems dedicated to that usage:
