Adrien

entry.title: Reversing and Adjusting Depreciation and Net Book Value
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We acquired an asset on 31 December 2024 with a useful life of one year. We have posted depreciation for the last ten months, but the audit team informed us that the asset was acquired with the wrong value and that part of the cost should go to an AUC.

How can we adjust the net book value of the original asset and reverse or adjust the posted ordinary and accumulated depreciation?

The original net book value was 1730970 and it should be 1442475.

The difference of 288495 should be transferred to the AUC.

The ordinary monthly depreciation posted was 144247 but it should have been 120206.

A total of 240410 should be reversed.

How can we adjust all these values correctly in the system?

entry.title: VOFM ‚Äì Custom Routine for Packaging Instruction Determination in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, during packaging instruction determination for production receipts with synchronous posting, the system automatically determines the main packaging instruction. However, the alternative packaging instructions are not displayed.

In my case, the selection of an alternative instruction is based on the Production Version, but this field is not available in the field catalog for condition-based determination. In the configuration step Define Schema for Packaging Instruction Determination, there is a ‚ÄúCondition‚Äù field. In on-premise systems, this would be implemented using a condition formula created in transaction VOFM.

I have seen SAP Notes related to VOFM enablement in Cloud for sales pricing determination (for example, Note 2885513). I also checked the documentation here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/e78cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US
but found nothing regarding packaging instruction determination.

My question is:
Is it possible to develop custom condition formulas for packaging instruction determination in SAP Public Cloud?
If yes, what is the correct approach?

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook (Part 2)
entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactors

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement
  • 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration
  • 3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration
  • 3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages
  • 3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration
  • 3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration
  • 3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication
  • 3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems
  • 3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series ‚Äì each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side ‚Äì Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating employee data from SAP SuccessFactors into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining employee data locally within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on Workforce Person master data replicated from the corporate HR system. This ensures that roles, organizational assignments, and reporting lines remain consistent across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date employee data is essential in Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), as many process steps are people-driven ‚Äì including incident reporting, assigning investigation responsibilities, approvals, and regulatory documentation. Moreover, EHS integrated workflow functionalities are heavily based on a role and responsibility concept, which depends on the correct assignment of persons within the organization.

In other words: Without employee integration, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot correctly identify, assign, or document the people involved in an incident or are responsible for EHS tasks.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post - focusing on the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Note: While this post focuses on the standard integration scenario using SAP SuccessFactors EC as the source, employee master data can also be replicated from other connected HR systems or SAP S/4HANA On-Premise / Private Cloud environments. In such cases, a customized integration flow can be implemented in SAP Integration Suite to transfer the workforce data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. If the integration to the relevant HR system already exists, this step can be skipped.

Reference to User Scenario (A) ‚Äì Incident Management

In part 1 "Introduction & Overview‚Äù, the User Scenario (A) Incident Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) clearly demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Employee Integration Matters

An internal maintenance technician is injured

The injured person must be identified as an employee, with job role, organizational unit, and location stored to support injury documentation, reporting and regulatory requirements.

A colleague nearby reports the incident in the system

The system must recognize the reporter as an employee with the correct role and permission to create an incident entry.

A First Aider records medical details in the Injury/Illness Log Entry

EHS needs accurate employee data to identify the certified First Aider and capture their involvement for documentation and accountability.

The Incident Manager is automatically notified and assigned

The Incident Manager must be derived from organizational structures, supervisory relationships, or assigned safety roles maintained in HR.

Corrective and preventive actions are assigned to employees

Task ownership, due dates, approvals, and completion tracking require valid employee master data to ensure accountability and reporting across the organization.

Learnings are shared across sites with operations and safety teams

Up-to-date organizational structures ensure that communication reaches the right target audience for safety awareness and training measures.

Without integrated employee data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify the injured person, reporter or First Aider,
  • Determine the responsible Incident Manager, or
  • Track assigned corrective actions across organizational units.

This makes the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors EC into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory first step before configuring Incident Management.

Note: When implementing Incident Management as shown here in the user scenario, please ensure that scope item 3FP ‚Äì Incident Management is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC) beforehand. This activation is required to enable the Incident Management processes and related configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud.

While this integration is a prerequisite for Incident Management, it is equally relevant across other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Emissions Management. In these scenarios, consistent employee master data provides the foundation for assigning roles and responsibilities, managing organizational structures, and ensuring accurate process execution and compliance. Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the employee data integration between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully set up the integration scenario for SAP EHS Public Cloud, several prerequisites must be met. These prerequisites ensure that employee master data can be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the predefined integration scenario delivered with scope item JB1 ‚Äì Maintain Employee Master Data.

Important: Activating scope item JB1 enables the required communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, allowing the predefined integration flows in SAP Integration Suite to securely exchange and replicate employee data between the two systems.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC tenant
  • SAP Cloud Integration tenant (SAP Integration Suite)

Certificate Setup:

  • Certificates are required only if certificate-based authentication is used for the connection (recommended for productive environments)
  • In our case, Basic Authentication was used for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for SAP SuccessFactors, which requires a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite instead of an X.509 certificate exchange.

Administrator Access: Admin users must be available across all three systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) / SAP Integration Suite

Scope Item Activation:

  • Scope item "Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)" must be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP SuccessFactors must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Employee Import Restriction:

  • Once employees have been replicated from SAP SuccessFactors EC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, do not manually create or upload the same employee (e.g., via Manage Workforce app). Mixing manually created records with replicated records can lead to data inconsistencies and replication conflicts.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the employee data integration based on the predefined JB1 ‚Äì Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central scope item. It outlines how workforce data is replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The JB1 scope item provides the standard integration scenario for workforce data replication and supports related HR data flows relevant for Incident, Risk, and Emissions Management. Accurate and consistent employee master data is crucial for these EHS use cases, as incidents, responsibilities, and corrective actions depend on properly linked workforce information.

Therefore, this section focuses on the JB1 ‚Äì Maintain Employee Master Data process, which serves as the foundation for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key JB1 Configuration Areas:

  • SAP SuccessFactors EC Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Integration Package Setup in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Monitoring and Operations

For a detailed documentation, please refer to the official JB1 content in the SAP Process Navigator - SAP for Me.

How to find JB1 setup instructions as a PDF

To view the process visualization, open JB1 ‚Äì 02 Maintain Employee Master Data in the SAP Process Navigator.

Select "Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 

"Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration

To prepare SAP SuccessFactors EC for the employee master data replication to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, several configuration steps must be completed upfront. In our setup, SAP SuccessFactors was already fully implemented and configured, and our focus was primarily on enabling the integration with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Nevertheless, we have summarized the key configuration steps below to outline the main areas that typically need to be in place to support the JB1 replication scenario. For a detailed, step-by-step configuration, the official SAP Best Practice documentation can be referenced (JB1 setup instructions ‚Äì chapter 3).

Provisioning Settings in EC

The configuration begins in SuccessFactors Provisioning, where core system settings must be enabled to support employee data replication. This includes activating EC core features, ensuring required language packs are available, and enabling the necessary integration add-ons and OData APIs. These provisioning settings form the technical foundation that allows EC to supply employee data to external systems, including SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Push Replication Setup (Optional but Recommended)

Employee data can be transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud either through scheduled replication jobs or by using push replication. Push replication enables near-real-time updates and is recommended for scenarios where timely employee data is needed, such as EHS processes. If enables, additional configuration is required to specify which employee changes trigger replication and to define the conditions under which data is pushed to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Data Model Configuration (HRIS & MDF)

To ensure compatibility with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, key elements of the EC data model should be validated and adjusted if necessary. This includes checking HRIS elements for correctness, making sure mandatory fields are maintained, and aligning field properties such as formatting, field length, and data type. MDF objects must also be reviewed for employee-related data elements so that required data can be successfully replicated. Aligning the data model upfront minimizes replication error and ensures that all data transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud meets the expected structure.

Company Structure and Cost Assignment Alignments

Employee data must be linked to the correct organizational units to enable downstream processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, including EHS. It is important to ensure that Legal Entities, Business Units, Departments, and Cost Centers are correctly structured and assigned. In some cases, custom fields may be required to support additional mapping between EC and S/4HANA, depending on the company‚Äôs organizational structure. A clear alignment of this data ensures that employees appear in the correct organizational context after replication.

Integration User and Authentication Setup

An integration user with appropriate permissions must be created to allow SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to retrieve employee data through EC APIs. This includes assigning the required OData API permissions and confirming that the chosen authentication method ‚Äì basic authentication or certificate-based authentication ‚Äì is correctly configured. Basic authentication is typically sufficient for testing or demonstration purposes, while certificate-based authentication is recommended for productive environments.

Optional EC Application Settings

In addition to the core configuration steps, EC provides optional settings that can enhance the quality of employee data replicated to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These include settings such as employee information, and contingent worker data. While not mandatory for the integration, these options can enrich the employee profile in the target system.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP SuccessFactors EC, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001 ‚Äì Employee Integration is used. Activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Setup illustration of Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001

As shown in the illustration above, the Communication Arrangement consists of two key components: an Inbound Communication User and a Communication System.

3.2.1 Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g. user SF_S4HC). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored later in the Security Material of SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems.

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app ‚ÄúMaintain Communication Users‚Äù.

Select "Maintain Communication User"

 If no suitable user exists, simply select ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create one.

Select New Communication User

Username and password can be freely defined but must be entered later in the Security Material section of the SAP Integration Suite for authentication.

Illustration of our Communication User

These steps align with chapter 5.2 ‚ÄúIntegration Credentials Configuration‚Äù in the JB1 setup instructions (pages 29‚Äì30). For more details on using Certificate-based Authentication instead of Basic Authentication, please refer to the corresponding JB1 guide section.

3.2.2 Communication System

The Communication System defines the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external system, in this case SAP Integration Suite. It contains system details such as URLs, authentication methods, and technical identifiers, forming the foundation for all Communication Arrangements that enable secure data exchange. Without a properly configured Communication System, no reliable integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP Integration Suite can take place.

In our setup, the SAP Integration Suite tenant served as the Communication System. If no system exists yet, a new one needs to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For basic incident management scenarios, this single system is sufficient. However, for additional integrations ‚Äì such as cost center replication or payroll posting etc. ‚Äì further configuration might be required (For reference, see chapter 4.1.2 ‚ÄúCreate Communication Systems‚Äù in the  JB1 setup instructions, pages 30-31).

To create the Communication System, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the ‚ÄúCommunication Systems‚Äù app.

Select "Communication Systems"

 If no suitable entry is available, create a new system by selecting ‚ÄúNew‚Äù.

Select New Communication System

 Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the Integration Suite tenant and proceed with the set up.

System Setup

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained ‚Äì including General Data, Technical Data, Log System ID, Business System ID, and the User for Inbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP Integration Suite tenant.

For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the JB1 setup instructions. In our setup, the Communication System was created with the settings illustrated below.

Illustration of our Communication System (1)Illustration of our Communication System (2)

 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement

The final step in the S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components ‚Äì the Communication User and the Communication System ‚Äì within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0001 ‚Äì Employee Integration).

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the ‚ÄúCommunication Arrangements‚Äù app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

Choose SAP_COM_0001 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication Scenario

Select Communication Scenario

After that, further setting up configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Select Communication System))

In our scenario, no additional configuration (e.g. cost center replication, address, or payment information) was required, so these fields remained empty.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Additional Properties))

The Inbound Communication User is automatically populated once the corresponding Communication System is selected. At the same time, the Inbound Service provided the service URL used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Inbound Services)

 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of employee data from SAP SuccessFactors is essential for Incident Management and other EHS processes. Any replication failure can prevent incidents from being assigned to the correct person or role, impacting compliance and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the Message Dashboard app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the JB1 integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the ‚ÄúAssign Recipients to Users‚Äú app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the "Assign Recipients to Users" app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users

 2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

  • Namespace: /WFD
  • Recipient Name: WFD_WORKER_INTEGRATION
  • Message Type: Application Error or Technical Error

Check if Recipients are assigned to User

 3. If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and the details above.

Add New User and assign New Recipient

Enter User ID

Assign Recipients to User

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages ‚Äì including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records ‚Äì allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides a consolidated view of all replication messages for the JB1 scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g., WFD_WORKER/1), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact EHS processes.

Message Dashboard Overview

3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration

3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration

In the previous step (chapter 3.2.3), we created Communication Arrangements in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to enable inbound communication from external systems. These arrangements ensure that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can safely receive employee master data from the SAP Integration Suite.

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the Integration Flow (iFlow) must authenticate against two endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì for employee master data via SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC ‚Äì which triggers the replication process when called by the iFlow

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data between the two systems.

Set up Security Material for Authentication against SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For communication with SAP SuccessFactors, the iFlow uses OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion, which requires creating a Security Material entry with a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite. This setup ensures secure authentication whenever the iFlow retrieves data from SAP SuccessFactors.

The highlighted process flow below illustrates where SAP SuccessFactors is triggered by the SAP Integration Suite:

JB1 Process (Maintain Employee Master Data)

For a detailed step-by-step guide on setting up OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion and Security Material in SAP Integration Suite, refer to this SAP Community Blog.

3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages

SAP provides preconfigured integration content for scope item JB1 as part of the standard best-practice setup. This allows a straightforward configuration process, since you can simply copy the predefined package into your own workspace. For our scenario, the following integration package was required:

  • SAPSuccessFactorsEmployeeCentralIntegrationwithSAPS4HANAEmployeeData

The package can be found in the Discover section of the SAP Cloud Integration workspace. Once copied, it includes all necessary Integration Flow (iFlow) required for employee master data replication between SAP SuccessFactors EC and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In the next step, we will configure these iFlows to establish the data exchange process.

Search for Integration Package in SAP Integration Suite

Copying the Integration Package

 

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.3 ‚ÄúCopying Integration Packages‚Äù (pages 55‚Äì56) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Initial Full Load:

After copying the integration package into your workspace, the first configuration step is the Initial Full Load. This ensures that all relevant employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC is replicated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud before any delta update occurs.

Why this is important: Accurate and up-to-date employee master data is essential across all EHS use cases, as it ensures that roles, responsibilities, and organizational structures are consistently reflected in safety and compliance processes. This is particularly critical for Incident Management, where incidents must be linked to the correct employees and supervisors. Without a complete initial load, subsequent data updates cannot be processed reliably.

Key Actions:

1. Set the Timer to Run Once: In the iFlow configuration, choose Run Once for the initial execution. This triggers a one-time full replication of all employee master data.

iFlow Settings for Timer

Note: After the initial load is complete, switch the timer to Schedule to Recur for delta replication.

Why is this needed? Because the initial load only runs once. If you leave the timer unchanged, no further updates will be replicated. By switching to a recurring schedule, you enable delta replication, which keeps employee data continuously up to date.

2. Configure Receivers: Next, open the iFlow and click ‚ÄúConfigure‚Äù. Two recipients must be set up:

iFlow Select Configure

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Receiver: Use the details from Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001. While Certificate-based Authentication is recommended for productive environments, Basic Authentication can be used for test setups. Enter the service URL of SAP_COM_0001 as the address of the receiver. 

Set up Receiver for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • SAP SuccessFactors Receiver: Configure OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for secure API calls. The address can be taken from the JB1 setup instructions (page 57). The Credential Name here is the same as the Security Material created in chapter 3.3.1.

Set up Receiver for SAP SuccessFactors

 3. Adjust Core Parameters

  • Set Initiate_Full_Load = TRUE for the initial run (reset to FALSE afterwards)
  • Define Company Codes and Workforce Type
  • Set the Full_Transmission_Start_Date to include all relevant employee records

Once deployed, the iFlow performs a complete replication of employee master data. This step establishes the foundation for all ongoing delta updates and ensures that EHS processes consistently reference the correct workforce context.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 ‚ÄúConfiguring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Initial Full Load‚Äù (pages 56‚Äì59) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Delta Replication:

After the initial full load has established the basic dataset in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the next step is to enable delta replication. This ensures that any changes in SAP SuccessFactors, such as new hires, terminations, or updates to employee information, are continuously synchronized with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Why this is important: Delta replication plays a key role in keeping employee master data current across all EHS use cases. Accurate and timely workforce is essential not only for Incident Management, but also for other processes like Risk- or Emission-Management, where employee roles and organizational responsibilities drive compliance and reporting accuracy. Without a delta replication, the system would remain static after the initial load, leading to outdated information and potential inconsistencies. By enabling the delta replication, updates are processed incrementally, reducing system load and improving overall efficiency.

Key Checks before Deployment:

To activate delta replication, ensure the following settings are applied (as mentioned in the initial load configuration):

  1. Timer: Set to Schedule to Recur with an appropriate frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes between 00:00 and 24:00).
  2. Parameter: Set Initial_Full_Load = FALSE to switch from full load to incremental updates.

All other configuration steps remain the same as for the initial load.

Result: Once deployed, the iFlow performs incremental updates instead of a full replication, ensuring that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud always reflects the latest employee master data for EHS and related business processes.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 ‚ÄúConfiguring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Delta Replication‚Äù (pages 60 ‚Äì 61) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration

In exceptional situations, it may become necessary to reset the delta synchronization configuration. This option is designed to reinitialize the replication process by clearing the stored delta markers, allowing the system to fetch data as if it were the first replication cycle.

When is a reset relevant?

  1. Correction of inconsistencies: If previous delta runs failed or resulted in incomplete updates, a reset ensures that all changes are captured.
  2. Testing and validation: For scenarios where a fresh replication cycle is required without performing a complete system reset.
  3. Troubleshooting: When resolving integration issues that cannot be addressed through standard delta processing.

By resetting the configuration, the system retrieves data from the earliest defined point, ensuring completeness. However, this approach should be applied with caution, as it can lead to significant data volumes being processed again.

How can the Reset be performed?

  1. Open the SAP Cloud Integration Web UI of your SAP Cloud Integration tenant and choose ‚ÄúMonitor‚Äù (under Design) from the top-level menu on the left.
  2. In the ‚ÄúManage Stores‚Äù block, choose the ‚ÄúVariables‚Äù tile. The available variables are displayed in the Global Data Store.
  3. To reset a replication scenario, delete the corresponding variable(s) from this list by choosing the ‚ÄúDelete‚Äù button next to the variable(s). The delete button for each variable is on the right side of the variable table in column ‚ÄúActions‚Äù. The table below specifies the variable name(s) of the variable(s) which needs(s) to be deleted to reset the delta sync configuration for the replication scenario / corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow).

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.5 ‚ÄúReset Existing Delta Sync Configuration‚Äù (pages 69 - 70) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that employee data replication runs smoothly across all systems involved in the JB1 integration scenario. Accurate employee data is the foundation for all EHS processes, as many scenarios ‚Äì such as incident tracking, risk assessments, and regulatory reporting ‚Äì depend on reliable workforce information. Inaccurate or incomplete replication can disrupt these processes and impact compliance or operational efficiency.

3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems

Employee Master Data Replication involves three layers:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Inbound Monitoring): As described in chapter 3.2.4, inbound replication is monitored using the Message Dashboard (AIF Monitoring). This allows administrators to review message statuses and reprocess failed messages if required.
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (Source Monitoring): In SAP SuccessFactors, replication activity can be monitored using the SFAPI Audit Log, which displays outbound replication calls and related processing information. While this functionality is available, it is not covered in detail here.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Middleware Monitoring): The SAP Integration Suite ensures that data flows correctly between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Monitoring focuses on the integration flow status, message processing, and error handling within the middle layer.

3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows:

1. Navigate to Manage Integration Content: Navigate to Monitor > Manage Integration Content to verify that the Integration Flow (iFlow) for employee replication is deployed and running. The status Started indicates that the flow is active.

Navigate to Manage Integration Content

 2. Monitor Message Processing: Under Monitor Message Processing, you can view detailed logs for executed messages.

Navigate to Monitor Message Processing

This view shows whether each message has been successfully processed or if any errors occurred.

Example of successfully completed Message Processing

3. Message Status Overview: The Message Status Overview aggregates statistics across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues.

Message Status Overview

(These steps correspond to chapter 6 ‚ÄúMonitoring of Replication Scenarios‚Äù (page 71) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing JB1 for employee integration in SAP EHS Public Cloud provided several key insights that are even important for similar projects:

1. Employee Integration is Mandatory: Accurate workforce data is the foundation for EHS processes. Without it, Incident Management cannot correctly identify the involved people, assign responsibilities, or ensure compliance.

2. Initial Load is Critical: A successful initial replication establishes the baseline for all subsequent updates. Any errors at this stage can lead to inconsistencies throughout the system.

3. Delta Replication ensures Timelines: Regular updates are essential to reflect organizational changes such as new hires or role adjustments. Without delta replication, the system remains static and operational risks increase.

4. Reset Delta Sync is a Fallback, not a Routine Step: This option is useful for correcting inconsistencies or re-initializing data during testing. However, it should be applied cautiously due to the potential for large data volumes.

5. Monitoring is Essential for Operational Reliability: Continuous monitoring of replication flows prevents disruptions. Tools like AIF monitoring in SAP S/4HANA and Execution Manager in SuccessFactors proved invaluable for early error detection.

6. Authentication Strategy Matters: While Basic Authentication is acceptable for demos or test environments, certificate-based authentication is strongly recommended for production to ensure security standards.

7. Organizational Data Alignment is Key: Mismatches between legal entities and company codes were identified as a common source of replication errors. Early validation avoids downstream issues.

8. Demo vs. Production Considerations: Simplifications used in demos (e.g., Basic Auth) needs to be adapted for production environments to ensure compliance and robustness.

9. Optional Data Can Become a Blocker: Missing or incorrect optional fields, such as bank details, can prevent successful replication. These fields should be validated early in the process.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal 
  • @qkroiss 
  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: SAP Certification Is Changing: What You Need to Know About the New Format
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve been following SAP‚Äôs certification updates, you‚Äôll know things are changing in a big way. The traditional multiple-choice exams are being replaced with a much more practical approach. I recently went through all the latest materials and sessions about the new SAP certification format, especially for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), and I want to share what I learned and how you can prepare.

Why Is SAP Changing Its Certification Format?

SAP wants certifications to mean more than just passing a test. The new format is designed to make sure certified professionals can actually do the work required on real SAP projects. Instead of just memorizing theory, you‚Äôll be asked to solve problems and perform tasks that you‚Äôd encounter in your day-to-day job. This shift is great news for both candidates and employers. Companies can trust that certified consultants are ready for hands-on work, and candidates can show they‚Äôre truly job-ready.

What‚Äôs Different About the New Exams?

The biggest change is the move to performance-based assessments. You‚Äôll be asked to complete tasks in a simulated SAP system, or respond to real-world scenarios, sometimes interacting with an AI avatar or submitting a video response. You can use SAP Help Portal, SAP Learning, and even SAP Joule (the AI tool) during the exam, just like you would on a real project. This open-book style makes the exam feel much more like actual work.

You also get to choose how you want to be assessed for some parts: either through an AI role-play or by uploading a video. After you finish, you‚Äôll receive instant feedback, including analytics on your technical depth and communication skills.

Role-Based Certifications and Staying Certified

SAP certifications are now tailored to specific job roles, such as developer, administrator, or architect. This means the exam content is more relevant to what you‚Äôll actually do in your role. Certifications aren‚Äôt permanent anymore. You‚Äôll need to complete a ‚Äústay-certified‚Äù assessment each year to keep your credential active. This helps ensure everyone stays up to date with the latest SAP technology and best practices.

Timeline for the New Format

The rollout starts in November 2025 for selected exams, including SAP BTP Administrator, SAP Build Developer, Solution Architect ‚Äì SAP BTP, SAP Business Data Cloud, and SAP Generative AI Developer. By 2026, all SAP certifications will use this new practical format.

What Hasn‚Äôt Changed?

You‚Äôll still get a digital badge when you pass, and the registration process is the same as before. If you already have a certification, it remains valid, but you‚Äôll need to follow the renewal process to keep it active.

How Should You Prepare?

Focus on building practical SAP skills. Spend time working in SAP simulation environments, and practice explaining SAP solutions clearly and simply. Get comfortable with timed tasks and AI evaluation, and make sure your laptop, internet, webcam, and audio all meet SAP‚Äôs technical requirements before exam day.

Spotlight on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Certification

The BDC certification is a great example of the new approach. It covers foundational knowledge and practical skills in SAP Business Data Cloud. The assessment includes technical knowledge of BDC, integration with SAP Business Warehouse, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. To earn the badge, you‚Äôll need to complete the recommended SAP Learning Journey and pass the C_BCBDC exam. Remember to renew your badge every year.

Exam questions breakdown from my attempt:

 

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC (40%)
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks (15%)

 

Tips for Success

Take your time and use the pause button to think before you answer. Break your responses into clear chunks, and don‚Äôt worry about giving too much information, there‚Äôs no penalty for being thorough. Read the feedback you get and use it to improve before your next attempt. And don‚Äôt rush; you have plenty of time.

Useful Links

Here are some resources that helped me:

  • SAP Certification Overview
  • SAP Certification in the Age of AI
  • SAP BDC Learning Journey
  • SAP Certification BDC

Final Thoughts

SAP‚Äôs new certification format is a big step forward. It‚Äôs designed to make sure credentials really mean something and that certified professionals are ready for real project work. If you‚Äôre preparing for the SAP Business Data Cloud certification, focus on practical skills, clear communication, and continuous learning. The future of SAP certification is here, and it‚Äôs all about being ready for the real world.

If you have questions or want to share your experience with the new SAP certification, I‚Äôd love to hear from you in the comments.

entry.title: Re: Non-billable items in service order template
entry.content:
Good day @PASEK 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Recurring Services- Missing Maintenance Plan type "Service Order", Service Processing Using a Service Order, Item Categories, Item Categories-Sales

In public cloud, due to clean-core restrictions, Service Order Templates are fixed. Thereby making it a non-editable item category. That also infers that:

  • You cannot add non-billable items to templates,
  • You cannot change item types after the order is created.
  • The Service Contract fully controls the billing relevance and not the Service Order.

My recommendation, therefore, is to keep service contract as the single billing driver, make use of informational Service Orders your maintenance plan generates, add only text or zero-price items in your template and avoid adding any billing relevant configuration at the Service Order level.

The Blog: Recurring Service in S/4HANA Service - Start with an Overview also provides some good insights.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Copy of Analytics Stories between Planning Areas in S...
entry.content:
Hello,

 

There isn't an easy way to copy Analytic Stories between Planning Areas, as of IBP 2511. 

Once you copy an Analytic Story, it will automatically copy the data source used (Planning Area) and the setting cannot be changed. What you can try:

1. Run the app job "Import Best Practice Analytics Stories" -> this will generate the standard Stories for your new Planning Area, then you can adjust them. At least it is faster than creating a story from scratch. 

2. Copy the custom Analytic Story -> add the new Planning Area in the "Data Source" tab, then apply a filter that will basically filter out any results from your initial Planning Area (example ABC ID = "D"), in this way the Analytic Story will only display the results of the new PA. (i admit i have not tested this yet). 

 

Regards!

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (1/3): Impactful Preparation and Demo
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens G√∂tz

Rolling out a global S/4HANA core template is never just a technical exercise ‚Äì it is rather a broader cultural shift for an organization. It‚Äôs the pivotal point where local expertise meets a standard global vision. The first two steps of the Fit2Standard approach - Local Units‚Äô Preparation and the System Demo ‚Äì carry more weight than they seem at the first glance.   

Handled well, these phases set the project on right track, highly reducing rework later in template validation and adoption. Shall they be handled, however, poorly, they create confusion, misalignment across an enterprise and weeks of unnecessary follow-up.

So, how does the right preparation phase look like for a successful Fit2Standard approach?

Local Units‚Äô Preparation: Four Weeks to Shape the Entire Rollout

The rollout begins with the preparation, which is not just an administrative warm-up. It is the point where each unit equips itself to speak with clarity and authority during the entire Fit2Standard implementation.

From the Fit2Standard roadmap (see image above), this phase seems simple and lean embracing onboarding, local information collection, and local team set-up. Nevertheless, in practice, it is much more strategic.

Local teams bring requirements, legal constraints, operational differences, tax rules and real-world transaction examples ‚Äì all the components that the program team can never know fully in advance. If this information is incomplete or delivered at a later stage, every subsequent Fit2Standard phases will be at risked or slowed down.

A strong preparation embraces the following five factors which have to be carried out in a consistent manner:

Upfront nomination of the correct team: a small, empowered group ‚Äî a local process owner, local finance/operations SME and an IT contact, ‚Äî becomes the voice of the unit / entity. This group of people are active decision-makers.

Creation of a solid basis: statutory rules and requirements, sample transactions, org charts, current process documentation, all create a solid basis for later comparison and meaningful usage.

Effective usage of the preparation period:  it provides the local teams to find a shared language with the central team through elevating the time for self-study, intro sessions, training on the S/4 Connect platform.

The System Demo: Bridging Local Reality and the Standard Framework

Following the preparation, comes the moment everyone is waiting for: the first live look at the S/4HANA core template.

In the Fit2Standard timeline, the System Demo is the bridge between preparation and analysis ‚Äî a shared stage where local expectations meet the standard design.

The Demo Workshop is designed to give the participants insight into the system landscape and infrastructure, end-to-end template processes and transaction flows.

In order to make the demo sessions rewarding for the entire subsequent rollout, it is important to secure a smooth collaboration between the local teams and the project team. Crucial factors of success are:

Realistic, Business-Ready Data

A demo is only credible if it uses meaningful master and transactional data. Realistic data allows users to recognize their business, trust the system behavior, and validate processes accurately.

Clear, Story-Driven Scenarios

A strong demo follows a real end-to-end business scenario‚Äînot isolated transactions. A narrative (‚Äúday in the life‚Äù) helps stakeholders understand how S/4HANA supports and improves their actual workflows.

Fully Prepared and Rehearsed Delivery

The system, roles, configuration, and presenters must be fully prepared. A smooth, well-rehearsed demo builds confidence; a disorganized one generates doubt and resistance.

Capturing Decisions and Actionable Outcomes

The value of a demo lies in its outputs. Clear decisions and assigned actions ensure the demo directly drives design progress instead of becoming a passive show-and-tell.

The demo is the moment when the abstract template becomes tangible for local teams. With proper preparation, teams move from questioning whether the model fits their context to identifying the areas that will require adjustments for their specific case. This mindset shift is the core of Fit2Standard.

Start Strong for a Smooth Fit2Standard Journey

Across many rollouts, one pattern consistently stands out: the results achieved in the final rollout directly depends on the effort put into the preparation phase.
Local Units‚Äô Preparation and the System Demo require relatively moderate effort but yet deliver a significant impact. When local teams commit early, approach it intentionally, the Fit2Standard workstream becomes organized, efficient, and transparent instead of reactive and cumbersome.
These early actions do more than simply initiate the process. They establish the tone, determine the pace, and build the foundation for a successful and scalable global template rollout.

***

Related to the main article: 
Main Article: A Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise (LINK)

entry.title: Re: Redirect navigation to extended ‚ÄúManage Central Purch...
entry.content:
We had a similar requirement and we solved this using authorizations. 

Use the same semantic object - action combination as the standard app, but the component points to the extended app in the tile + target mapping of your extended app.  In the role, only the new target mapping is added. 

This should allow you to open the app from other apps using cross app navigation, but will open the extended app since only this is present in the role.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...

You maintain the condition records for your new condition type with the condition key as a key field. See how it is done for VA00.

entry.title: Credit Risk Analyzer: Limits Management - Money Market (Fixed Deposits) and Forex (Spots)
entry.content:
Credit Risk Analyzer helps to manage default risk of counterparties by tracking limits assigned to them on real time basis. This blog describes limits management for both Money Market (Fixed Deposits) and Forex (Spots).  

For limits management, following are essential configurational elements: Limit Types, Determination Procedure, Default Risk Rule, and Derivation of Risk Rule. Starting with necessary configurations, the blog will cover required cutover activities as well as relevant Fiori Apps, and SAP tables.

Configuration steps: -

Enablement of Credit Risk Analyzer starts with activation of necessary financial objects: -

  • IMG > TRM > Basic Analyzer Settings > Automatic Integration of Financial Objects in Transaction Master Data > Activate/Deactivate Automatic Integration of Financial Objects >
    • Money Market: Activate/Deactivate Financial Object Integration
    • Foreign Exchange: Activate/Deactivate Financial Object Integration

 

 

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Activate Integrated Default Risk Limit Check >

Configurations related to Determination Procedure and Default Risk Rule are very integral part for the proper tracking of default risk under Credit Risk Analyzer: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Definitions > Define Determination Procedures >

Determination Procedure for Fixed Deposits: -

Determination Procedure for Forex - Spots: -

Note:

  1. Forex Forward transactions will utilize credit risk limit only, whereas only Settlement Risk is applicable to Forex Spots  transactions.
  2. Irrespective of the transaction type (i.e., 101 - Spot, 102 - Forward and others) entered while creating a FX transaction, the system will treat the FX deal as FX Spot if the Value Date is within the number of spot days (configurable items), otherwise it is treated as FX Forward transaction.   

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Definitions > Define Default Risk Rule >

For Fixed Deposits: -

For Forex Spots: -

Now, the mapping of Determination Procedure and Default Risk Rule: -

Last and most important configuration node for Limit Management is Limit Types: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Limit Management > Define Limit Types >

For Fixed Deposits: -

For Forex Spots: -

Under Assigned Limit Characteristics folder, we used Company Code and Business Partner, so that each counterparty can be assigned limit at the level of company code.

Cutover Activities: -

IMG > TRM > Credit Risk Analyzer > Basic Settings > Derive Default Risk Control Parameters >

This is derivation of Default Risk Rule for both the product types i.e., Fixed Deposits and Spots.

IMG > TRM > Basic Analyzer Settings > Automatic Integration of Financial Objects in Transaction Master Data > Customize Classic Derivation >

  • Money Market: Derive Default Risk Control Parameters for MM Transactions
  • Foreign Exchange: Derive Default Risk Control Parameters for Foreign Exchange

Similarly, for Forex Spots as well.

Fiori Apps: -

  • Manage Limits (TBL1)
  • Review Limit Utilizations (TBLB)
  • End-of-Day Processing (KLNACHT)

SAP tables: -

  • VTBLS ‚Äì Limits: Mapping Logical ‚Äì Physical Keys
  • VTBLV - Limits
  • VTBLIS ‚Äì Limit Utilization: Summarization

During cutover, we should first maintain / upload the limits of each of the counterparty, and then simulate the limits check during contract creation: -

I sincerely hope this blog covers Credit Risk Analyzer comprehensively from configuration to cutover. Open to your feedback and experience.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...
entry.content: You must create variant condition keys using transaction VK30. You must create a condition type with flag 'variant cond' set. Etc. See also F1 help of that flag. You maintain the condition records for your new condition type with the condition key as a key field using VK11/12/13. See how it is done for VA00. In VC you create a multi-value reference chrematistic that refers to structure SDCOM-VKOND using CT04. Assign it to the class of your KMAT using CL02. Then use transaction PMEVC to create a procedure to set the condition key as value for the reference cstic and use the $SET_PRICING_FACTOR as described in online help. With that, VC hands it over to pricing, which uses it to find a condition records for the given key and applies the factor when calculating the condition value from the condition rate that was maintained in the condition record.

Hello!

There is no setting or hard stops for the number of approvers that can be assigned to workflow but best practice recommends limiting the approval steps so that items are processed efficiently and to avoid any bottlenecks in the process. 

Sometimes less is more. The more complex the workflow steps it will negatively impact timely approvals.

entry.title: Re: Looking for Global Hierarchy CDS views / APIs keyword...
entry.content:
Good day @R_S2 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Global Hierarchies, Using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Apps for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration, SAP HANA Core Data Services

Answer to question 1:

There are no released CDS views and no OData APIs for Global Hierarchies in public cloud. This is common in public cloud that some fragments are not delivered. To my knowledge, the only ones you can access are for financial statements and not for Global Hierarchies.

Answer to question 2:

Yes. Due to the public clouds clean-core principle, it is normal because Global Hierarchies are UI-only with no backend API exposure. Alternatively, I recommend exporting from UI, you can also consider building your custom hierarchy manually, use RPA or Datasphere (this will depend on if SAP releases hierarchy extension)

In summary, Manage Global Hierarchies app is delivered in the public cloud but without exposing any backend CDS views or APIs for reading the hierarchy. So, the ones you listed are not available. The current clean-core compliant alternatives include, exporting hierarchies from the app, reconstructing them manually in custom CDS, using SAP Build RPA or loading them into BTP/Datasphere.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Financial Statement Apps Show Old FSV Structure of Mi...
entry.content: After migrating an FSV to Global Hierarchies, some reporting apps, such as Balance Sheet/Income Statement and the Multidimensional version, may continue to display the old structure because these apps do not automatically consume all Global Hierarchy based FSVs. This behaviour is expected and app dependent rather than a migration issue. Please see KBA 3438291 in this regard.

entry.title: SAP Central Business Configuration: Activate Your SAP Business AI Features Centrally and Flexibly
entry.content:
Managing your SAP Business AI features is more straightforward than you might think: We offer a tailored view on AI features that matter to you, with the option to activate or deactivate them anytime.

You can simply log on to SAP Central Business Configuration, AI-assisted scoping and configuration services. Here, all the AI features relevant to you, depending on the SAP solutions you‚Äôre running, are displayed centrally. There are two ways to go about the activation: Depending on the AI features in question, you can instantly activate them yourself or you can have them activated by creating a support case. The AI features for SAP Sustainability Control Tower are the first features enabled for instant activation. For those, and many more planned for the future, you won‚Äôt need to create a support case. Instead, you can activate or deactivate them directly via the UI, unleashing value in seconds.

 Screenshot of SAP Central Business Configuration, AI-assisted scoping and configuration services

This free-of-charge service is a game-changer for you as SAP cloud customers, providing you with the autonomy and flexibility to manage AI features according to your specific business needs anytime. This also aligns with our vision for SAP Central Business Configuration as the central scoping and configuration tool, not only allowing AI feature activation but also enabling you to take all your scoping decisions centrally and autonomously. Stay tuned for more!

For all other AI features, the system for now guides you seamlessly to create a support case and provides you with all the information needed to do so. To learn more about the current step-by-step process, please check out this video:

Video on how to activate and deactivate SAP Business AI features via support case

entry.title: Extracting/Splitting Json String in SAP HANA using Table Function(SQL)
entry.content:
Source Data : TABLE

JSON_STRING

IDJSON_STRING
1[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"}]
2[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"}]
3[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"},{"code":"MI004","descr":"Donald Trump"}]

ID 2 and 3 have multiple code and descr 

In order to split/ extract the Json string in such a way that,

The code and descr should be splitted/extracted for same ID's which results in multiple rows.

 

FUNCTION "XYZ_JSON" ( ) 

RETURNS TABLE (ID NVARCHAR(50),
               CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
               TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
		       )

LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY DEFINER AS
BEGIN

 -- Create a temporary table to store the final results

 DECLARE result_table TABLE ( 
                   ID NVARCHAR(50),
                   CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
                   TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
				   );

 -- Declare working variables

 DECLARE current_row_id INT; -- Holds the row ID for the current row

 DECLARE remaining_string NVARCHAR(5000); -- Holds the remaining string to process

 DECLARE code_match NVARCHAR(255); -- Stores the currently matched value

 DECLARE descr_match NVARCHAR(255);

 DECLARE i INT; -- Match occurrence counter

 DECLARE cursor input_sql for SELECT ID,JSON_STRING, OCCURRENCES_REGEXPR('code":"' IN "JSON_STRING" ) as occur_code
 FROM "TABLE/CAL.VIEW";

 -- Loop through each row of the input table

  FOR cur_row AS input_sql

     -- Replace this with your actual table name

     DO

     -- Initialize variables for processing the current row

      current_row_id := :cur_row.id; -- Current row ID

      remaining_string := :cur_row.json_string; -- Current row's string to process

      IF cur_row.occur_code = 0 OR cur_row.occur_code IS NULL THEN

           INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (cur_row.id, cur_row.json_string, NULL);

      END IF;



        FOR i IN 1..cur_row.occur_code DO


           code_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('code":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

           descr_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('descr":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

          -- Check if a match is found


           IF code_match IS NOT NULL THEN

                -- Add the match to the result table

                INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (current_row_id, code_match, descr_match);

              ELSE

                -- Exit the loop when no more matches are found

                 BREAK;

           END IF;

        END FOR;

   END FOR;

    -- Output the final results

 return SELECT * FROM :result_table;

END;

Calling the table function.

select * from "XYZ_JSON"();

 

IDCODE_VALUETEXT_VALUE
1MI007James Bond
2MI007James Bond
2MI005Max Well
3MI007James Bond 
3MI005Max Well
3MI004Donald Trump

entry.title: Re: Missing "Payment details" tag in XML Facturae (public...
entry.content:
Good day @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thank you for your question.

In addition to the link @HenrikeGrtecke provided , the public cloud only displays <PaymentDetails> node in Spanish FACe XML if you have fully maintained the supplier‚Äôs bank data and the payment method requires bank details. Due to public cloud‚Äôs clean-core principle, the system suppresses tags unless you have provided all required data. I suggest you verifying your supplier IBAN, default bank account, payment method configuration and your mapping version in Define eDocuments. If those are correct, then rebuild the eDocument.

If PaymentsDetails is still missing,

  1. Check and correct your Master data. This often solves the problem as inconsistencies in master data are often the source.
  2. You can consider enabling PaymentDetails through mapping enhancement (use Define eDocument mapping to extend mapping by adding a conditional rule e.g., if supplier bank exists, then generate PaymentDetails. Map: IBAN, BranchCode and BankName. This is compliant with the public cloud clean-core principle.
  3. Another option is to use company code bank instead (this alternative is also allowed by Spain) because some FACe scenarios accept the company‚Äôs receiving bank instead of Supplier‚Äôs. You can switch to company code bank in mapping.
  4. If your system is missing the Payment details node completely, I suggest you raise an incident.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Spain Facturae, Code Flow When XML is Submitted from the eDocument Cockpit

Creating Electronic Document for Sales Billing Documents for Public Entities - Web Service

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im SAP S/4HANA-Projekt bei Aalberts hydronic flow control
entry.content:
Kathleen Regener berichtet √ºber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt. Die zentrale Erkenntnis: Eine Community braucht mehr als nur Infrastruktur ‚Äì sie braucht den richtigen Zeitpunkt, aktive Moderation und Key-User, die etwas Greifbares haben, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

√úber das Projekt und die Ausgangssituation

Kathleen Regener, PMO und Lead Change Management bei Aalberts hydronic flow control, berichtete in der SAP Training und Change Kaffee-Ecke √ºber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im Rahmen der konzernweiten S/4HANA-Transformation. Das Unternehmen bietet ganzheitliche L√∂sungen f√ºr Heiz-, K√ºhl- und Sanit√§rsysteme in Geb√§uden an. Das Projekt umfasst die Abl√∂sung von 6 verschiedenen ERP-Systemen f√ºr insgesamt 800 Enduser.

Die Besonderheit: Die Key-User wurden nicht ausgew√§hlt, sondern konnten sich f√ºr das Projekt bewerben. Am Ende konnten √ºber 100 motivierte Key-User gewonnen werden, die die √Ñnderungen mittragen wollten. Diese wurden in lokale Key-User und Power User aufgeteilt. Die lokalen Key-User waren die Ansprechpartner f√ºr das Projektteam und wurden f√ºr ihre Rolle freigestellt. Die Power User unterst√ºtzten nach verf√ºgbarer Zeit.

Struktur der Key-User-Community

Das Projektteam bestand aus Domain Process Ownern (DPOs), Technical Process Ownern (TPOs) und den Key-Usern. F√ºr die Global Template Phase wurden zus√§tzlich Global Key-User aus den Niederlanden, Deutschland und Frankreich eingebunden, die in die Workstreams Warehouse, Sales, Production, Supply Chain und Finance aufgeteilt waren.

Abbildung 1: Struktur des Projektteams mit DPOs, TPOs, Key-Usern (Global und lokal) und Power Usern

Projektphasen und Rollout-Strategie

Nach der Template-Phase wurden die Global Key-User zu lokalen Key-Usern und im ersten Rollout in den Niederlanden und UK eingesetzt. Die √ºbrigen Key-User gingen in eine Projektpause.

Diese Projektpause warf zentrale Fragen auf:

  • Wie bleibt man mit allen in Kontakt?
  • Wie k√∂nnen die Key-User zu einem Team zusammenwachsen?
  • Wie k√∂nnen wir sicherstellen, dass wir alle relevanten Informationen mit allen teilen?
  • Wie teilt man Lessons Learned aus den einzelnen Waves?

Aufbau der Community-Infrastruktur

Die Entscheidung fiel auf den Aufbau einer Teams-basierten Community mit verschiedenen Kan√§len. Der Start erfolgte mit einem offiziellen Kick-Off f√ºr alle Key-User. Es wurde eine Hausordnung erstellt, die das Verhalten in der Community regelte. Die Key-User erhielten eine Teams-Schulung, um die Umgebung optimal nutzen zu k√∂nnen.

Inhalte der Key-User-Community

Die Community bot ein umfassendes Angebot:

Workshop-Unterlagen:

  • Stressmanagement
  • Umgang mit Widerst√§nden
  • Train-the-Trainer-Unterlagen

Dokumentationen:

  • Quick Reference Cards
  • Projekt- und SAP-Glossar
  • FAQ zu Projekt und S/4HANA
  • Rollenbeschreibungen

Kommunikation und Austausch:

  • Raum f√ºr Fragen
  • Raum f√ºr Erfolgsstories
  • Raum f√ºr Lessons Learned
  • Projektinformationen und Timeline
  • Zentraler Meeting Hub
  • Regelm√§√üige Communication Starter

Ein Feedback-Channel wurde eingerichtet. Fragen wurden so beantwortet, dass die Antworten f√ºr alle Key-User sinnvoll nutzbar waren und im gesamten Team geteilt wurden.

Herausforderungen in der Praxis

Trotz der umfassender Vorbereitung gestaltete sich der Start schwierig. Die Reaktionen auf Communication Starter beschr√§nkten sich meist auf ein Daumen-hoch. Nach einem halben Jahr lautete das Fazit: Wir hatten keine Community, sondern ein Publikum. Die Informationen wurden aufgenommen, aber es fand keine wirkliche Interaktion statt.

Die neun zentralen Herausforderungen

Kathleen identifizierte neun konkrete Herausforderungen:

  • Keine Reaktionen der Key-User an uns als Change Management
  • Doppelrolle (Projekt und Tagesgesch√§ft) f√ºhrte zu Zeitproblemen bei Key Usern
  • Die Community hat nicht gelebt - es gab keine echte Interaktion
  • Unsicherheit beim Teilen: Key-User aus Wave 1 wussten nicht, was sie mit anderen Key-Usern teilen k√∂nnen
  • Fehlende Fragestellung: Key-User aus inaktiven Waves wussten nicht, was sie fragen k√∂nnen
  • Projektinformationen konnten nicht geteilt werden, da teilweise noch keine Entscheidungen getroffen waren oder das System noch nicht fertig war
  • Regelm√§√üige Check-Ins wurden nicht genutzt, da sich Key-User noch nicht vom Projekt betroffen f√ºhlten
  • Unterschiedliches Onboarding von Key-Usern und Power Usern
  • Geringe Teilnahmequote an Umfragen

Die zentrale Erkenntnis war: Der Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Aufbau der Community war falsch gew√§hlt.

Lessons Learned und Anpassungen

Eine Umfrage zeigte, dass die Key-User Beispiele, Tipps und Best Practices wollten, ihnen aber nicht bewusst war, dass sie selbst Input liefern m√ºssten. Das Selbstbewusstsein, selbst zur Community beitragen zu k√∂nnen, fehlte.

Konkrete Anpassungen in Wave 2

Abbildung: Change Management Lessons Learned und implementierte Verbesserungen

Das Change Management implementierte acht zentrale Verbesserungen:

  1. Onboarding-Phase und Toolkit f√ºr Key-User der n√§chsten Wave
  • Alle betroffenen lokalen Key-User und Power User wurden zum Kick-Off eingeladen
  • Geb√ºndelte Informationen in Landessprache
  • Hausaufgaben und Systemzugriff f√ºr die Vorbereitungsphase
  1. Statt Umfragen f√ºr Lessons Learned ‚Üí feste Termine f√ºr Feedback
  • Gezielte Fragen in pers√∂nlichen Terminen
  • Mehr direktes Feedback
  1. Erh√∂hung der Kommunikationsfrequenz
  • Zwei bis drei Communication Starter pro Woche
  • Mehr Bewegung in der Community
  1. Auf Wunsch: Aufnahme der DPOs und TPOs
  • Mehr Sicherheit f√ºr Key-User
  • Direkter Zugang zu Entscheidungstr√§gern
  1. Bi-weekly Community Meeting ‚Üí monatliches Meeting
  • Nur f√ºr Key-User der aktuellen Wave
  • In Landessprache
  • Mit Vorab-Fragen √ºber den Feedback-Kanal
  1. Einf√ºhrung des Projekt-Glossars
  • Besseres Verst√§ndnis f√ºr pausierte Key-User
  • Einheitliche Sprache im Projekt
  1. Anpassung/Trennung der einzelnen Umfragen
  • Wave-bezogene Umfragen
  • Angepasst an die jeweilige Projektphase
  1. Buddy-System f√ºr Key-User aus Wave 1 und 2
  • Erfahrene Key-User unterst√ºtzen neue Key-User
  • √úber Teams-Tag-Funktion organisiert
  • Austausch bleibt sichtbar f√ºr andere

Schulung und Training

Die Key-User wurden in zwei Schienen geschult: im Systembereich und vom Change Management im Bereich Trainingsgestaltung, Umgang mit Widerst√§nden und Umgang mit Endusern. Die Schulungsunterlagen waren Aufgabe der Key-User, wurden aber von den DPOs reviewed. Enduser wurden einbezogen, um zu pr√ºfen, ob das Level f√ºr gute Schulungen erreicht wurde.

Die Enduser-Trainings werden von den Key-Usern geplant und durchgef√ºhrt. Die Key-User stehen nach dem Go-Live als Hypercare-Support zur Verf√ºgung und sind danach erste Ansprechpartner f√ºr die Enduser. Die Trainingsunterlagen werden auf einer Enduser-SharePoint-Seite f√ºr alle zug√§nglich abgelegt und sind √ºber SAP Enable Now nachtr√§glich verf√ºgbar.

Bei der Trainingsplanung durften die Key-User die Gruppengr√∂√üe selbst festlegen, was zu mehr Wohlbefinden f√ºhrte. Es wurden Dry Runs veranstaltet, bei denen die Key-User ihre Classroom-Trainings vor dem Projektteam vorf√ºhren und Feedback erhalten konnten. Templates wurden bereitgestellt, um die Key-User zu entlasten.

Rolle des Change Managements

Das Change Management wurde erst mit diesem Projekt aufgebaut. Intern lastet die Arbeit auf einer Person (=Kathleen), unterst√ºtzt von drei Personen eines Implementierungspartners. Ein Community Lead aus den Key-Usern war geplant, konnte aber aufgrund von Zeitmangel nicht umgesetzt werden. Das Change Management √ºbernahm daher wieder die Moderation.

Die Kommunikation an das Management war wichtig, um sicherzustellen, dass die Key-User Zeit f√ºr ihre Projektarbeit bekommen und nicht mit 150 Prozent belastet werden. Das Change Management nutzte SAP Enable Now f√ºr die Erstellung von Lernpfaden f√ºr neue Kollegen um das Onboarding optimal vorzubereiten.

Erkenntnisse aus der Diskussion in der Community Session

Die Teilnehmenden an der Session teilten zahlreiche eigene Erfahrungen. H√§ufig genannte Herausforderungen waren √úberlastung der Key-User, Sprachbarrieren, regionale Arbeitsweisen, uneinheitliche Anforderungen und fehlende Ressourcen.

Was funktioniert in der Praxis?

Formate f√ºr erfolgreiche Communities:

  • Pr√§senztreffen und direkter Austausch
  • Zwei Stunden Treffen alle zwei Wochen mit der Projektleitung
  • Zweimal monatlich eine Stunde via Teams
  • Subgruppen nach Lokationen
  • Regelm√§√üige Calls mit fester Agenda
  • Moderierte Online-Plattformen
  • Informelle Treffen wie Kaffeeroulette

Unterst√ºtzungsma√ünahmen:

  • Train-the-Trainer-Seminare
  • Change-Management-Trainings
  • Konfliktmanagement-Training
  • Ambassador-Netzwerke
  • Templates f√ºr Schulungsunterlagen
  • Dry Runs mit Feedback
  • Tandem-Ans√§tze bei ersten Schulungen
  • Zus√§tzliche Testressourcen

Engagement f√∂rdern ‚Äì denn Engagement ist eine der gro√üen Herausforderungen in Communities:

  • Niedrigschwellige Formate wie Polls
  • Belohnungen f√ºr Key-User wie Special Events
  • In manchen F√§llen monet√§re Anreize
  • Lessons-Learned-Sessions
  • Gemeinsame Retrospektiven
  • Social Events ‚Äì feiern von Erfolgen

Innovative Ans√§tze:

  • Kaffeeroulette √ºber Teams: Zwei bis drei User werden per Zufall f√ºr eine Viertelstunde zusammengef√ºhrt
  • Networking Lunch mit Matching nach Interessen
  • Themenvorschl√§ge f√ºr informelle Treffen

Konkrete Tipps f√ºr die Praxis von Key-User Netzwerken

Auch wenn es nun evtl. Dopplungen gibt versuche ich hier nochmals Tips von Kathleen sowie den vielen Community Teilnehmenden hier aufzuf√ºhren. 

Timing und Planung

Timing beachten: Den richtigen Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Community-Start w√§hlen. Key-User brauchen etwas Greifbares, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

Einheitliches Onboarding: Alle Key-User-Gruppen von Anfang an gleich abholen, um unterschiedliche Wissensst√§nde zu vermeiden.

Wave-bezogene Planung: Umfragen und Meetings an die jeweilige Projektphase anpassen.

Kommunikation und Moderation

Aktive Moderation: Communities brauchen aktive Moderation und regelm√§√üige Impulse. Communication Starter allein reichen nicht.

Kommunikationsfrequenz erh√∂hen: Zwei bis drei Impulse pro Woche setzen, um Bewegung in die Community zu bringen.

Management einbinden: F√ºhrungskr√§fte √ºber den Zeitbedarf der Key-User informieren.

Sprache und Verst√§ndnis

Sprache anpassen: Bei internationalen Projekten Meetings und Unterlagen in Landessprache anbieten.

Technische Hilfsmittel nutzen: MS Teams mit Co-Pilot und Teams Professional f√ºr √úbersetzungen nutzen.

Glossar erstellen: Sicherstellen, dass alle in einer Sprache sprechen durch ein Projekt-Glossar.

Entlastung und Unterst√ºtzung

Entlastung schaffen: Key-User durch Templates, Dry Runs, Tandem-Ans√§tze und zus√§tzliche Ressourcen (z.B. beim Testen) aktiv unterst√ºtzen.

Didaktische Unterst√ºtzung: Power User oder Autoren unterst√ºtzen bei der Unterlagenerstellung.

Backfill organisieren: Neue Mitarbeitende einstellen oder interne Umverteilung f√ºr Daily Business.

Formate und Tools

Pr√§senz erm√∂glichen: Wo m√∂glich, Pr√§senztreffen oder zumindest regelm√§√üige Online-Meetings mit fester Agenda organisieren.

Buddy-Systeme nutzen: Erfahrene Key-User mit neuen Key-Usern vernetzen.

Tool-Wahl: Abh√§ngig von Kommunikationsgewohnheiten im Unternehmen (Teams, Slack, SharePoint).

Subgruppen bilden: Nach Lokationen, Workstreams oder Waves organisieren.

Erwartungsmanagement

Erwartungen managen: Nicht erwarten, dass alle aktiv mitmachen. In Communities sind oft nur ein bis zwei Prozent wirklich aktiv.

Publikum vs. Community: Verstehen, dass Community-Bildung Zeit braucht.

Zusammenfassung

Der Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt ist komplex und braucht Zeit. Die initiale Infrastruktur allein reicht nicht aus. Key-User befinden sich in einer Doppelrolle zwischen Daily Business und Projekt und brauchen aktive Unterst√ºtzung, klare Strukturen und das Gef√ºhl, nicht allein zu sein.

Entscheidend ist, Key-User nicht zu √ºberfordern, sondern durch Templates, Schulungen und Tandem-Ans√§tze zu entlasten. Sprachbarrieren und unterschiedliche Wissensst√§nde sollten aktiv adressiert werden. Der richtige Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Community-Start ist wichtig. Key-User brauchen etwas Konkretes, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

Die Anpassungen in Wave 2 zeigten Wirkung: einheitliches Onboarding, h√∂here Kommunikationsfrequenz, Meetings in Landessprache, Buddy-Systeme und die Einbindung der DPOs und TPOs.

Change Management ist kein Nice-to-have, sondern essenziell f√ºr den Projekterfolg. Die Erkenntnis, dass viele Herausforderungen trotz unterschiedlicher Branchen √§hnlich sind, zeigt uns auch wieder den Wert des Austauschs in der Community.

Weiterf√ºhrende Links und Ressourcen

SAP Community

  • SAP Training and Change Management Community
  • Dokumentation der Kaffee-Ecke Sessions und n√§chster Termin

Kommende Sessions

  • Walk Me Praxisbeispiel - Webinar mit Stada (12/2025) / Walk Me Learning Arc - Infosession zur Learning Komponente (Januar 2026) / Enable Now zu Walk Me Transition - Roundtable (Februar 2026) ‚Äì Infos und Anmeldung hier
  • Kaffee-Ecke ‚Äì Change & Training Retrospektive 2025/ Ausblick 2026 - 18.12.2025

√úber die Kaffee-Ecke: Die SAP Training and Change Management Kaffee-Ecke ist eine monatliche Community Session, die jeden dritten Donnerstag im Monat stattfindet. Sie bietet Raum f√ºr Austausch, Good Practices und Lessons Learned rund um Training, Learning und Change Management in SAP-Projekten.

Bei Interesse an einem Impuls in kommenden Sessions oder Fragen zur Community meldet Euch gerne.

entry.title: Implementing reliable versioning in SAP HANA using SQL triggers
entry.content:
Recently I worked on data versioning and thought it could be interesting for someone else üòäWhether you are tracking configuration changes, business rules, pricing tables, or workflow definitions, versioning ensures that updates are auditable, deterministic, and consistent. 

In this post, I'm going to share my thoughts how to implement versioning with statement-level triggers, solve typical challenges, and ensure version increments occur exactly once per relevant change.

I implemented versioning at the database level using SQL triggers, ensuring changes are tracked automatically and consistently. In this blog post I‚Äôm going to simplify the business versioning logic, so we can concentrate as only on the technical part. Furthermore I used HANA system versioning tables, but it is out of the scope in this post. Please be aware that this is just a small part of the real use case.

Use Case Overview

Imagine we have two tables:

  1. Entity A: Stores entity A metadata including its version. Each A_id column has a ‚Äúversion‚Äù column.
  2. Entity B: Stores entity B entries that reference a A_id. 

Whenever new rows are inserted into the table B, the corresponding entity A‚Äôs version must be incremented. This ensures that any change in usage of a rule automatically updates its version. 

Requirements

  • Insert/Update N rows into Entity B with the same A_id at once ‚Üí entity A version increments once, not N times.
  • Insert rows into Entity B with different A_ids ‚Üí each entity A version should increment once.

I implemented a statement-level trigger combined with temporary transaction-scoped tables.

Table Setup

CREATE TABLE "A" (
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
version INT
);
CREATE TABLE "B" (
b_id NVARCHAR(10),
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
description NVARCHAR(100)
);

To ensure that versions will be incremented once per transaction, two help tables are needed. We are going to track which a_ids have already been processed using:

CREATE GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE TMP_A_PROCESSED (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
) ON COMMIT DELETE ROWS;

CREATE TABLE TMP_A_NEW (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
);

The first table remembers which a_ids have already been incremented in the current transaction. The second table collects a_ids inserted by the current statement. 

Next we will need a versioning trigger. 

CREATE TRIGGER UPDATE_VERSION
AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE
ON B
REFERENCING NEW TABLE NEW_ROWS 
FOR EACH STATEMENT
BEGIN
INSERT INTO TMP_A_NEW (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM :new_rows
WHERE a_id NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_PROCESSED));
UPDATE A t
SET "VERSION" = "VERISON" + 1
WHERE t.a_id IN (SELECT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
INSERT INTO TMP_A_PROCESSED (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
DELETE FROM TMP_A_NEW;
END;

Do not forget to turn off autocommit or wrap your inserts/updates in a procedure! TMP_A_NEW table can be defined as a global temporary table too. It is even better, so you will avoid data deletion inside a trigger.

This example can be extended by adding more tables where the versions will be increased in a chain. 

Conclusion

Implementing versioning logic using SAP HANA SQL triggers offers a robust and automatic way to ensure data consistency across related tables.

The provided example should be considered only as my personal experience.
